    颈项门

    　　　　黄帝素问

    　　　　　金匮真言论

    　　东风生于春，病在肝，俞在颈项。故冬不按蹻，春不鼽衄，春[春　原缺，据《素问》金匮真言论补。]不病颈项。　　【注　俞者，经气之所注也，盖脏气实则病气，脏气虚则病脏也。按蹺者，按摩导引，引阳气之通畅于四肢也。冬时阳气伏藏，若导引其四出，则无以奉春生夏长之气，是以有鼽衄颈项之经病矣。春病在颈，邪热而迫于经者，鼽衄，别出下项，则为颈项之病矣。】[1p]

    Ancient and Modern Compendium of Medical Literature, Volume 166

    Neck Door

    Huangdi's Canon of Medicine

    True Words of the Golden Chamber

    The east wind arises in spring, and diseases are in the liver, affecting the neck. Therefore, in winter one should not press the acupoints, and in spring one should not suffer from nasal bleeding; there should be no illness in the neck during spring. 【Note: The term "yu" refers to the channels through which the vital energy flows. When the internal organs are full, it leads to disease; when they are deficient, it causes organ disease. "Anqiao" refers to massage and guiding exercises, facilitating the flow of yang energy throughout the limbs. In winter, the yang energy is hidden; if one attempts to promote its outward flow, it cannot support the energies of spring and summer growth, thus leading to nasal bleeding and neck issues. In spring, when the disease is in the neck, it's due to external heat forcing its way through the channels, causing nasal bleeding that emerges from the lower neck, which constitutes illness in the neck.】[1p]

    　　　　　脉要精微论

    　　推而下之，下而不上，头项痛也。
    　　 【注　推而下之，下而不上者，其气下盛上虚，当主头项痛也。】
    　　　　　玉机真脏论

    　　大骨枯槁，大肉陷下，胸中气满，喘息不便，内痛引肩项，期一月死。真脏见，乃予之期日。　　【注　内痛者，肺受其伤，肺之俞在肩背，故痛引肩项也。肝病而已传及于所胜之脏，故当期以本月之内而死也。真脏脉见，如循刀刃责责然，如按琴瑟弦。预之期日，当死于庚辛日之薄暮也。】　　大骨枯槁，大肉陷下，胸中气满，喘息不便，内痛引肩项，身热，脱肉破(月囷)，真脏见，十日之内死。　　 【注　肺病，故痛引肩背；传及于心，故身热也。夫心主血而生于肾脏之精，血气盛则充肤热肉，心肾伤而精血衰，故曰脱肉破(月囷)。[2p]

    On the Essentials of Pulse Diagnosis

    When the pulse pushes down and does not rise, it indicates a headache.

    On the True Organs of Jade Mechanism

    The major bones are withered, the flesh is sunken. The chest is full of Qi, making it hard to breathe; internal pain radiates to the shoulders and neck, with a prognosis of death within one month. When the true organ's pulse is observed, I give it a timeframe.

    The internal pain indicates lung injury, with the lung's correspondences found in the shoulders and back, hence the pain radiates there. If liver illness has transmitted to the organ it governs, then the prognosis is death within this month. The true organ’s pulse feels like pressing along the sharp edge of a knife, or like plucking the strings of a guqin. The expected date of death will be at twilight on a Geng or Xin day.

    The major bones are withered, the flesh is sunken. The chest is full of Qi, making it hard to breathe; internal pain radiates to the shoulders and neck, accompanied by fever and the falling away of flesh, with a prognosis of death within ten days.

    The lung is affected, hence the pain radiates to the shoulders and back; if it has affected the heart, this causes the fever. The heart governs blood, which is generated from the essence of the kidneys. When blood and Qi are abundant, there is heat in the flesh. If both the heart and kidneys are damaged, leading to declining essence and blood, this is why it is called the falling away of flesh.[2p]

    真脏脉见大而虚，如羽毛中人肤，病传于心，故期以十日之内死。盖心不受邪，故死之速也。】　　大骨枯槁，大肉陷下，胸中气满，腹内痛，心中不便，肩项身热，破(月囷)脱肉，目眶陷，真脏见，目不见人，立死；其见人者，至其所不胜之时则死。　　 【注　本经曰：肾病者，大小腹痛。肾传之心，故心中不便。心传之肺，肺传之肝，故肩项身热。肝传之脾，故目眶陷也。真脏脉见搏而绝，如指弹石辟辟然。如目不见人，肾之精气已绝，故立死。其见人者，余气未尽，至所不胜之时而死，谓当死于日昃也。夫肾为生气之原，生绝于下，故死之更速也。】[3p]

    The true pulse appears large and weak, like a feather on human skin, the illness transmitted to the heart, hence projected to die within ten days. The heart does not suffer from evil influences, thus the swiftness of death. The major bones are dry and emaciated, the flesh sinks down, there is fullness in the chest, pain in the abdomen, discomfort in the heart, heat in the shoulders and body, the flesh falls away, the eye sockets are sunken, the true pulse is visible, and one does not see others—the individual dies suddenly; those who do see others die when they reach a point beyond endurance.

    The classic text states: For kidney disease, there is pain in the lower abdomen. The kidneys affect the heart, leading to discomfort in the heart. The heart affects the lungs, which influence the liver, hence the heat in the shoulders and body. The liver affects the spleen, resulting in sunken eye sockets. The true pulse exhibits sudden interruptions, like a finger striking a stone with a crisp sound. If one cannot see others, it means the essence and energy of the kidneys have been exhausted, thus death occurs suddenly. Those who see others still have residual energy; they die when they reach their limit, specifically at sunset. The kidneys are the source of life’s energy, emanating from below, thus hastening death.[3p]

    　　　　　风论

    　　胃风之状，颈多汗，恶风，食饮不下，膈塞不通，腹善满，失衣则(月真)胀，食寒则泄，诊形瘦而腹大。　　 【注　颈有风池、风府，乃经脉之要会，故颈多汗。胃腑受邪，故饮食不下，膈塞不通，腹善满也。胃气不足，则身以前皆寒，腹胀满，是以形寒则(月真)胀，饮冷则泄者，胃气虚伤也。胃者肉其应，腹者胃之郛，故主形瘦而腹大。】[4p]

    On Wind

    The symptoms of stomach wind include excessive sweating in the neck, aversion to wind, difficulty in consuming food and drink, blocked diaphragm, frequent abdominal fullness, abdominal distension when unprotected from the cold, and diarrhea when consuming cold food. Upon examination, the body appears thin, but the abdomen is large.
    (Note: The neck has pivotal points like Fengchi and Fengfu, which is why there is excessive sweating. The stomach channel is affected by evils, leading to difficulty in eating and drinking, blockage of the diaphragm, and abdominal fullness. When stomach qi is deficient, the front of the body feels cold, and abdominal distension occurs; thus, if the person feels cold, the abdomen distends, and if they drink cold, they experience diarrhea, indicating damage from weak stomach qi. The stomach corresponds to flesh, and the abdomen reflects the stomach's reservoir, hence the appearance of being thin yet having a large abdomen.)[4p]

    　　　　　厥论

    　　少阳厥逆，机关不利者，腰不可以行，项不可以顾。　　 【注　少阳主枢，是以少阳气厥而机关为之不利也。颈项者，乃三阳、阳维之会；腰脊者，身之大关节也。故机关不利者，腰不可以转行，项不可以回顾。】　　手太阳厥逆，耳聋泣出，项不可以顾，腰不可以俯仰，治主病者。　　 【注　手太阳所生病者，耳聋。小肠主液，故逆则泣出也。夫心主血脉，小肠主液而为心之表，小肠气逆则津液不能荣养于经脉，是以项不可以顾，腰不可以俯仰，盖腰项之间，乃脉络经俞之大会也。】[5p]

    Discussion on Reversal Symptoms

    When the lesser yang is in reversal, the mechanisms are not functioning properly; one cannot walk with the waist, nor turn the neck. [Note: The lesser yang governs the joints, hence when its energy is in reversal, the mechanisms are impaired. The neck is where the three yangs converge; the waist and spine are the major joints of the body. Therefore, if the mechanisms are impaired, one cannot turn to walk with the waist, nor turn the neck.]

    When the hand of the greater yang is in reversal, there is deafness and tears flow out; one cannot turn to view, nor look up or down with the waist, as it indicates ailments that the physician must address. [Note: The conditions produced by the hand of the greater yang include deafness. The small intestine governs fluids, hence its reversal results in tears. The heart governs blood vessels, and the small intestine, which pertains to liquid, is the exterior of the heart. When the energy of the small intestine is in reversal, the fluids cannot nourish the channels, leading to the inability to turn the neck or move the waist. The area between the waist and neck is where the major channels and collaterals converge.][5p]

    　　　　　热论

    　　岐伯曰：伤寒一日，巨阳受之，故头项痛，腰脊强。　　 【注　太阳之气主皮毛，故伤寒一日，太阳受之。阳气在上，故头项痛。背为阳，故腰脊强。】
    　　　　　腹中论

    　　帝曰：有病膺肿，颈痛，胸满腹胀，此为何病？何以得之？岐伯曰：名厥逆。
    　　　　　至真要大论

    　　太阴司天，湿淫所胜，则沉阴且布，雨变枯槁，胕肿，骨痛，阴痹。阴痹者，按之不得，腰脊强，头项痛。　　 【注　湿淫于上，是以沉阴且布，草木枯槁，得化气之雨而变生胕肿阴痹，皆感寒湿气，病在阴者名曰痹，故按之不得也。肾主骨，而膀胱为之腑，故腰脊头项骨痛。】　　太阴之胜，火气内郁，疮疡于中，流散于外，病在胠胁，甚则心痛热格，头痛，喉痹，项强。　　 【注　阴湿之气淫于外，则火气内郁而疮疡于中矣。湿热之气流散于外，则及于风木而病在胠胁。甚则心痛者，木甚而传于火也。[6p]

    Discussion on Febrile Diseases

    Qibo said: If febrile disease lasts for one day, it affects the Greater Yang, hence the pain in the head and neck, and the stiffness in the lower back. 【Note: The solar qi governs the skin and hair; therefore, if febrile disease lasts one day, it is influenced by the solar energy. Since the Yang energy is upward, there is pain in the head and neck. The back is associated with Yang, hence the stiffness in the lower back.】

    Discussion on Abdominal Conditions

    The Emperor asked: There is a disease characterized by swelling in the chest, pain in the neck, fullness in the chest, and abdominal distension. What is this disease? How does one acquire it? Qibo replied: This is called "reversal of qi."

    Discussion on the Essential Truths of the Great Principles

    When the Greater Yin governs the heavens, if dampness overcomes it, then it sinks and disperses, causing rain, withering, swelling, bone pain, and Yin obstructive syndromes. Yin obstruction means that pressing on it yields no effect, with stiffness in the lower back and pain in the head and neck. 【Note: The dampness dominating above causes the Yin to sink and disperse, causing plants to wither and resulting in swelling and Yin obstruction, all triggered by cold dampness. The disease in the Yin is termed "obstruction," hence pressing yields no effect. The kidneys govern bones, and the bladder is their associated organ, thus causing pain in the lower back, head, and neck bones.】

    When the Greater Yin prevails, fire energy becomes congested internally, leading to ulcers inside and dispersing externally, affecting the sides. In severe cases, there may be heart pain and heat afflictions, headaches, throat obstructions, and stiffness in the neck. 【Note: When dampness and heat are excessive outside, fire energy becomes congested internally, causing ulcers. When the heat and damp energy disperses outward, it affects the sides. In severe cases, heart pain results when wood energy is excessive and transmits to fire.】[6p]

    热格头痛，喉痹项强者，风火之气与湿气相杂，从颈项而上于巅顶也。】　　太阳之胜，热反上行，头项囟顶脑户中痛，目如脱。　　 【注　热反上行者，太阳之气，随经上入脑，还出别下项。太阳经脉起于目内眦，故目如脱也。】　　太阴之复，湿变乃举，头项项　《素问》至真要大论作「顶」。痛重而掉瘈尤甚。　　 【注　头项痛重而掉瘈尤甚者，所谓因于湿，首如裹，湿气不攘，大筋緛短，小筋弛长，緛短为拘，弛长为痿也。】　　少阴司天，客胜则鼽嚏，颈项强，肩背瞀热，头痛。　　 【注　少阴司天，初气乃太阳寒水，头项强，肩背瞀热，头痛，太阳寒水之气胜也。】　　诸痉项强，皆属于湿。
    　　 【注　此五脏之气而发见于形气也。】[7p]

    Headaches with neck stiffness and throat tightness are caused by a mixture of wind, heat, and dampness, ascending from the neck to the crown of the head. When the Yang energy overwhelms, heat rises, causing pain in the head and neck, making the eyes appear protruded. The rising of heat refers to the Yang energy that ascends through the channels into the brain, then descends into the lower neck. The return of the Yin results in dampness rising, leading to heaviness and increased sensitivity in the head and neck. This heaviness and sensitivity are particularly severe because of dampness, as if the head is wrapped. When dampness is not expelled, the large and small muscles become affected—tightness leads to rigidity, while relaxation leads to weakness. When the Lesser Yin governs, if the external force overcomes, it results in sneezing, neck stiffness, heat in the shoulders and back, and headaches. This reflects the dominance of cold, watery Yang energy manifesting in stiffness and pain in the head and neck. All manifestations of stiffness and cramps in the neck are related to dampness, reflecting the气 (qi) of the five zang organs as they present in the physical form.[7p]

    　　　　灵枢经

    　　　　　邪气脏腑病形篇

    　　邪之中人，中于项则下太阳。
    　　 【注　以太阳之循颈项而上干于头面也。】
    　　　　　论疾诊尺篇

    　　视人之目窠上微痈，如新卧起状，其颈脉动时咳，按其手足，上窅而不起者，风水肤胀也。　　 【注　足太阳之脉起于两目而下出于颈项，太阳之上寒水主之，大阳之气运行于肤表，此水随气而溢于皮肤之间，故目窠微肿。颈脉动而肤胀咳者，水留于皮毛而动其肺气也。风水者，因外受于风，风行而水涣也。】
    　　　　　寒热病篇

    　　五脏身有五部：伏兔一；腓二，腓者，腨也；背三；五脏之腧四；项五。此五部有痈疽者死。　　【注　伏兔，肾之街。腨者，脾之部。背乃肺之俞。五脏俞谓五椎之心俞也。项者，肝之俞。本经曰：痈疽之发，不从天下，不从地出，积微之所生也。故五部之有痈疽者，乃五脏渐积之郁毒，外应于血气之不和而为之也。故五部有此者死。】[8p]

    The Classic of the Spiritual Pivot

    On Pathogenic Qi and Disease of the Organs

    When the pathogenic factor enters a person and affects the neck, it descends to the Taiyang.
    [Note: This refers to the Taiyang's influence as it moves up the neck and affects the head and face.]

    On Diagnosis of Diseases

    When examining a person's eye sockets, if there is a slight swelling resembling a new awakening, and when the neck pulse is active, there is coughing upon pressing the hands and feet, it indicates swelling from wind water.
    [Note: The pulse of the feet at the Taiyang originates at the two eyes and exits at the neck. The cold water from the Taiyang primarily governs this area. The Yang energy flows on the skin's surface, and thus the water mingles with the air and surges between the skin, causing slight swelling in the eye sockets. If the pulse moves and there is skin swelling accompanied by coughing, it indicates water retention in the skin, affecting the lung’s qi. Wind water arises from external exposure to wind, leading to the dispersion of water.]

    On Cold and Heat Diseases

    The five internal organs correspond to five regions of the body: the Futu (Hidden Rabbit) is one; the knee is two (the knee refers to the spleen); the back is three; the five organ points are four; and the neck is five. Anyone with a carbuncle in these five areas is bound to die.
    [Note: Futu refers to the area of the kidneys. The knee corresponds to the spleen's region. The back relates to the lung's points. The points of the five organs are called the heart points of the five vertebrae. The neck corresponds to the liver's points. This text states: the emergence of a carbuncle does not arise from heaven or earth, but from the accumulation of subtleties. Therefore, the presence of a carbuncle in these five areas represents the gradual accumulation of toxic stagnation from the five organs, responding externally to the disharmony of blood and qi. Thus, anyone with this condition in these regions is bound to die.][8p]

    　　　　　本输篇

    　　缺盆之中，任脉也，名曰天突。
    　　 【注　当缺盆中央动脉是。】
    　　一次任脉侧之动脉足阳明也，名曰人迎。　　 【注　挟喉两旁之动脉是。】
    　　二次脉手阳明也，名曰扶突。
    　　 【注　挟喉动脉之后，曲颊之前一寸后是。】　　三次脉手太阳也，名曰天窻。
    　　 【注　手阳明之后，当曲颊之下是。】　　四次脉足少阳也，名曰天容。
    　　 【注　曲颊之后，当耳之下是。】　　五次脉手少阳也，名曰天牖。
    　　 【注　耳后当完骨上是。】
    　　六次脉足太阳也，名曰天柱。[9p]

    This section discusses the pulse points in relation to different meridians.

    1. At the center of the hollow of the abdomen is the Ren meridian, known as Tiantu (Heavenly Trough).
    2. The first pulse at the side of the Ren meridian corresponds to the Yangming meridian, known as Renying (Human Response).
    3. The second pulse corresponds to the Shaoyang meridian, known as Futuo (Supporting Trough).
    4. The third pulse corresponds to the Taiyang meridian, known as Tiankuang (Heavenly Window).
    5. The fourth pulse corresponds to the Shaoyang meridian, known as Tianrong (Heavenly Appearance).
    6. The fifth pulse corresponds to the Shaoyang meridian, known as Tianyou (Heavenly Opening).
    7. The sixth pulse corresponds to the Taiyang meridian, known as Tianzhu (Heavenly Pillar).[9p]

    　　 【注　挟项大筋中是。】
    　　七次脉颈中央之脉，督脉也，名曰风府。　　 【注　凡此论三阳之脉，循序而上于颈项，应阳气之出于地外，而任督二脉出于肾，而通先天之阴阳也。】　　足阳明，挟喉之动脉也，其俞在膺中。手阳明次在其俞外，不至曲颊一寸。手太阳当曲颊。足少阳在耳下曲颊之后。手少阳出耳后，上加完骨之上。足太阳挟项大筋之中发际发际　原缺，据《灵枢》本输篇补。。　　 【注　此论阳气之上下，以应天气之升降也。】
    　　　　　寒热篇

    　　黄帝问于岐伯曰：寒热瘰疬，在于颈腋者，皆何气使生？岐伯曰：此皆鼠瘰寒热之毒气也，留于脉而不去者也。　　 【注　寒热之毒气，下藏于脏，上通于颈腋之间，留于脉而不去，则为瘰疬者，此肾脏先天之水毒也。天开于子，天一生水，其毒在外，故名曰鼠。夫颈腋之脉，少阳之脉也，少阳乃初阳之气，生于先天之水中，而少阳又与肾脏经气相通，故本经曰少阳属肾。[10p]

    [Note: The major tendons are among the neck and back.]

    The central pulse in the neck is the governing vessel, called Fengfu (Wind Palace). [Note: In discussing the three Yang meridians, they ascend sequentially through the neck, responding to the Yang qi emerging from outside the earth, while the Ren and Du vessels originate from the kidneys and connect to the primordial Yin and Yang.] The Yangming in the foot is the artery alongside the throat, with its point located in the chest. The hand Yangming follows, situated outside its point, not extending more than an inch to the cheek. The hand Taiyang is at the cheek curve. The foot Shaoyang is behind the cheek near the ear. The hand Shaoyang exits behind the ear and ascends above the occiput. The foot Taiyang runs alongside the major tendon of the neck, starting from the hairline. [Note: This discusses the rise and fall of Yang qi to correspond to the ascent and descent of atmospheric conditions.]

    Cold and Heat Section

    The Yellow Emperor asked Qi Bo: What kind of qi gives rise to cold, heat, and scrofula located in the neck and armpits? Qi Bo replied: These are all due to the toxic qi of cold and heat from the mouse, which lingers in the meridians and does not leave. [Note: The toxic qi of cold and heat, stored in the organs below and connecting to the neck and armpits, becomes scrofula. This is the water poison of the kidney as primordial. When the heavens open at Zi (the Rat), the first heaven generates water; its poison is external, hence called ‘mouse.’ The pulse at the neck and armpits is from the Shaoyang meridian; Shaoyang is the initial Yang qi, arising within the primordial water, and it also connects with the qi of the kidney, thus this meridian is said to belong to the kidney.][10p]

    】　　黄帝曰：决其生死奈何？岐伯曰：反其目视之，其中有赤脉上下贯瞳子，见一脉，一岁死；见一脉半，一岁半死；见二脉，二岁死；见二脉半，二岁半死；见三脉，三岁而死。赤脉不下贯瞳子，可治也。　　 【注　厥阴少阳之形脏在于心下中焦之部分，而二气皆本于肾脏之所生。瞳子者，水脏之骨睛也。赤脉从上而下贯瞳子者，水脏之毒气，上交于包络之火脏，火脏之毒气，复下交于水脏之骨睛，此为阴阳交者，死不治。盖毒气在于阴阳之脏内往来不能出于末，而从脉溃，故为不治之恶疾也。一脉一岁死者，水脏之毒甚也。二脉二岁死者，水脏之毒传之于火脏也。三脉三岁死者，毒气分于二脏之间也。盖毒之专者，为害重，故死之速。分者，死之迟也。一脉半者，一二之间也。二脉半者，二三之间也。】[11p]

    The Yellow Emperor said: How can one determine life and death? Qi Bo replied: Observe the eyes; within them are red veins that run through the pupil. If one vein is seen, death will occur in one year; if one and a half veins are seen, death will occur in one and a half years; if two veins are seen, two years until death; if two and a half veins are seen, two and a half years until death; if three veins are seen, death will occur in three years. If the red vein does not run through the pupil, healing is possible.

    (Note: The organ shapes of the Jue Yin and Shao Yang are located in the lower part of the heart and middle burner, and both types of energy originate from the kidneys. The pupil is the 'bone eye' of the water organ. The red vein running up and down through the pupil signifies toxic energy of the water organ, which collides with the fire organ's toxic energy and subsequently affects the water organ's 'bone eye.' This interaction of yin and yang leads to an incurable death. The toxicity inside the organs prevents movement and release, hence it ruptures the veins, resulting in a severe illness. The single vein signifies severe toxicity of the water organ, causing one-year death; two veins signify the toxicity spreading to the fire organ, leading to a two-year death; three veins mean the toxic energy is distributed between the two organs, causing a death after three years. The more concentrated the toxicity, the more severe the harm, thus leading to quicker death. The 'fraction' indicates a slower death. One and a half veins fall between one and two years; two and a half veins fall between two and three years.)[11p]

    　　　　　痈疽篇

    　　痈发于颈，名曰夭疽。其痈大，以赤黑，不急治则热气下入渊腋，前伤任脉，内熏肝肺。熏肝肺，十余日而死矣。　　【注　颈乃手足少阳阳明血气循行之分部，故不急治，则热气下入渊液，渊液乃足少阳胆经穴，在腋下三寸，盖从外而将入于内也。任脉居阳明、少阳四脉之中，故前伤任脉。内熏肝肺，此在外腑经之毒，内熏于脏，故至十余日而死。】
    　　　　金匮要略 【汉　张机】

    　　　　　项强急

    　　病者身热足寒，颈项强急，恶寒，时头热，面赤，目赤，独头动摇，卒口噤背反张者，痓病也。若发其汗者，寒湿相得，其表益虚，即恶寒甚。发其汗已，其脉如蛇。
    　　　　　颈脉动

    　　寸口脉沉滑者，中有水气，面目肿大有热，名曰风水。视人之目裹上微拥，如蚕新卧起状，其颈脉动，时时咳，按其手足上陷而不起者，风水。[12p]

    Treatise on Abscesses

    Abscesses occurring on the neck are called premature abscesses. These abscesses are large, with a red-black color; if not treated urgently, the heat will descend into the depths of the armpit, damaging the Ren meridian and internally affecting the liver and lungs. If the liver and lungs are affected, death will occur within ten days.

    Urgent Stiffness of the Neck

    The patient has a fever and cold feet, with a stiff and urgent neck, chills, intermittent heat in the head, a flushed face, red eyes, and a distinct shaking of the head, along with suddenly clenched jaws and an arched back; this signifies tetanus. If sweating occurs, cold and dampness will worsen the condition, and the exterior becomes more deficient, leading to intensified chills. After sweating, the pulse feels like a snake.

    Pulsation of the Neck

    If the cun pulse is deep and slippery, there is water present. If the face is swollen and hot, it is called wind-water. If the eyes appear slightly protruded, like a newly hatched silkworm, and there is a pulsation in the neck with frequent coughing, accompanied by a hand or foot that sinks when pressed and does not rebound, it is also wind-water.[12p]

    　　　　千金方 【唐　孙思邈】

    　　　　　九漏

    　　凡项边腋下先作瘰疬者，欲作漏也，宜禁五辛、酒、面及诸热食。　　凡漏有似石痈，累累然作疬子，有核在两颈及腋下，不痛不热。治者，用练石散敷其外，内服五香连翘汤下之。已溃者，治如痈法。诸漏结核未破者，火针，针使着核结中，无不瘥者。何谓九漏？一曰狼漏，二曰鼠漏，三曰蝼蛞漏，四曰蛊漏，五曰蚍蜉漏，六曰蛴螬漏，七曰浮沮漏，八曰瘰疬漏，九曰转脉漏。
    　　　　疮疡全书 【宋　窦汉卿】

    　　　　　项疽毒

    　　此毒因五脏受毒，气壅血枯，伏在风府之间，恶证也。当用败毒流气饮治之，后用内托流气饮。
    　　　　　风毒颈痈

    　　有人肥壮，素能饮酒，酷暑远行，酒醉居于舟中，卧于风内，又为日色暑气相侵，并有七情所干，归家不免于色欲，颈项间忽痛如失枕之状，其名曰何？乃风热锁喉毒也。久则红色绕于肩背，坚硬难消。急服清暑疏风散。[13p]

    Thousand Gold Prescription
    (Tang Dynasty - Sun Simiao)

    Nine Leaks

    When lumps appear first on the neck or armpits, they are likely to be leaks. It is advisable to avoid five pungent foods, wine, flour, and all hot dishes. These leaks resemble stone carbuncles, appearing as lumps with the cores located in both necks and under the arms, causing no pain or heat. For treatment, one should apply a powder of calcined stone externally and internally take a Five Spice and Forsythia decoction to purge them. If they have already ruptured, treat as for carbuncles. For unbroken lumps, a fire needle should be used, inserting the needle into the center of the lump for complete resolution. What are the Nine Leaks? They are: first, wolf leak; second, rat leak; third, mole cricket leak; fourth, sorcery leak; fifth, ant leak; sixth, larvae leak; seventh, floating leak; eighth, scrofula leak; ninth, turning pulse leak.

    Complete Book on Sores and Ulcers
    (Song Dynasty - Dou Hanqing)

    Neck Carbuncle Toxin

    This toxin arises from the five organs being poisoned, with Qi stagnation and blood depletion, lurking between the wind pavilion, indicating a serious condition. One should use a Dispersing Toxin and Flowing Qi Decoction to treat it, followed by an internal Releasing Flowing Qi Decoction.

    Wind Toxin Neck Carbuncle

    There are robust individuals, well accustomed to drinking alcohol, who travel in intense heat, become inebriated while aboard a vessel, and lie exposed to the wind. Additionally, when influenced by the sun’s warmth and emotional disturbances, they return home unable to resist desires, and suddenly experience pain in the neck, reminiscent of a lost pillow. What is this? It is the poison of wind and heat locking the throat. Over time, redness develops around the shoulders and back, becoming hard and difficult to resolve. Urgently take a Cooling Heat and Releasing Wind Powder.[13p]

    　　　　　瘰疬

    　　此证手少阳三焦经主之。大抵此经多气少血，因惊忧思虑，故生。此疾初起生于耳下及项间，并颐颔下，至缺盆，在锁子骨陷中，隐隐皮肤之内。初生如豆，渐长如李核之状，或一粒，或三五粒，按之则动而微痛，不发热，惟午后微熟，或夜间口干，饮食少思，四肢倦怠，则坚而不溃，溃而不合，皆因气血不足，往往变为劳瘵，自觉红肿或上或下、或左或右，连串三五个，破溃遍项，渐流脓血，致成瘰疬。独形者为结核，续欲连结者为瘰疬，但此证原不系膏粱之变，因虚劳气郁所致，宜以益气养荣之药治之，其疮自消。若金石暴悍之剂，血气愈损不能生矣。若不速治，必致丧生也。马刀疮与瘰疬，同系少阳胆经主之，此经亦多气少血，或在耳之前后，或在耳下连及颐颔，或在胸及胸侧，或在两胁，久坚不溃，皆谓之马刀疮也，故多坚少软，脓白如稀糊似泔水状，治者求水清可也。形表如蛤者，为马刀疮。[14p]

    Luo Li (Scrofula)

    This condition is primarily governed by the Hand Shaoyang Sanjiao Meridian. Generally, this meridian is characterized by an abundance of qi and a deficiency of blood, arising from shock, worry, and contemplation. This disease initially manifests beneath the ear and between the neck, extending down to the jaw and into the supraclavicular fossa, appearing subtly beneath the skin. Initially, it emerges like a bean and gradually grows to resemble a plum pit, sometimes appearing as one, or three to five nodules. When pressed, they move slightly and cause mild pain; there is no fever, only a slight maturation in the afternoon or nighttime dryness in the mouth, diminished appetite, and fatigue in the limbs. They remain firm and do not rupture; when they do rupture, they do not heal, all due to insufficient qi and blood, often transforming into phthisis. Patients may feel redness and swelling that can appear above or below, to the left or right, often in clusters of three to five, rupturing and releasing pus and blood, leading to the formation of scrofula. Singular lumps are termed tubercles; those that tend to connect are referred to as scrofula. However, this condition is not caused by rich foods but rather by a combination of deficiency and stagnant qi. Therefore, it requires treatment with tonics to nourish qi and blood, allowing the sores to resolve naturally. Using harsh or drastic medicines will damage the blood and qi further and hinder recovery. If not treated promptly, it could lead to fatality.

    Madao Chuang (Horse-Cutter Ulcer) is also governed by the Shaoyang Gallbladder Meridian, which, like the Sanjiao Meridian, is characterized by an abundance of qi and a deficiency of blood. This may appear in front of or behind the ear, beneath the ear extending to the jaw, or in the chest and sides, or along the flanks, persisting firm without breaking. All of these are regarded as Madao Chuang. Thus, they are more firm than soft, with pus appearing white and resembling thin soup or dirty water. Those treating it should seek a clear liquid. If the external appearance resembles that of a clam, it is classified as Madao Chuang.[14p]

    　　　　河间六书 【金　刘完素】

    　　　　　颈痛

    　　膺肿颈痛，胸满腹胀，上实下虚，气厥而逆，阳气有余郁于胸也，不可针灸，宜服顺气汤、小茯苓汤主之。　　肾热者，腰痛胻酸，苦渴数饮食热，热争则项痛而强，胻寒且酸，足下热不欲言。经曰：汗出脉躁盛，一死；脉不与汗相应其病，二死；狂言失志者，三死。皆是怫郁结不能解散，以致危殆。
    　　　　　瘰疬论

    　　夫瘰疬者，经所谓结核是也。或在耳前后，连及颐颔，下连缺盆，皆为瘰疬。或在胸及胸之侧，下连两胁，皆为马刀。手足少阳主之。此二经多气少血，故多坚而少软，脓白而稀如泔水状，治者求水清可也。如瘰疬生在别经，临时于《铜人》内，随其所属经络部分对证之穴灸之，并依经内药用之。独形而小者为结核，续数连结者为瘰疬，形表如蛤者为马刀。[15p]

    Jing Tong (Neck Pain)

    For swelling and pain in the neck, with fullness in the chest and distention in the abdomen, it indicates excess above and deficiency below, with qi stagnation and reversal. This condition has an abundance of yang qi trapped in the chest; acupuncture is not appropriate. It is advisable to take a remedy to smooth qi, like Shunqi Decoction or Xiaofuling Decoction. If there is kidney heat, symptoms will include lower back pain and soreness, thirst with a desire for hot drinks; when heat stirs, it causes pain in the neck and tightness, while the legs are cold and sore, making the person unwilling to speak. The classic states: If sweating occurs with a floating pulse, one dies; if the pulse does not respond to sweating, two die; if one speaks crazily and loses one's faculties, three die. All these result from stagnant emotions that cannot be relieved, leading to peril.

    Luo Li Lun (On Lumps)

    Lumps are what the classics refer to as tubercles. They might appear before or behind the ear, extending to the jaw, connected below to the supraclavicular fossa—these are all lumps. If present in the chest or on the side of the chest, extending down to both sides of the lower ribs, these are termed "Ma Dao." The Shao Yang meridian governs these cases. This meridian has more qi than blood, hence it tends to be hard rather than soft, with pus being white and thin like rinse water. The practitioner should seek clear water for treatment. If lumps arise in other meridians, one should follow the corresponding acupuncture points as per the classic "Bronze Man" and use medicinal treatments according to the meridian involved. A single small lump represents a tubercle, while several connected forms are referred to as lumps; those that resemble a clam shell on the surface are called "Ma Dao."[15p]

    　　　　明理论 【金　成无己】

    　　　　　项强

    　　伤寒项强，何以明之？太阳脉起于目内眦，上额交巅，上入络脑，还出别下项，循肩臂，内挟脊，抵腰中。经曰：太阳之病，头项强痛而恶寒。以太阳感受风寒，则经脉不利，而颈为之急，项为之强耳。伤寒颈项强急者，太阳表证也，必发散而解之可也。太阳病，项背强八八，反汗出恶风者，桂枝加葛根汤主之。太阳病，项背强八八，无汗恶风者，葛根汤主之。是皆发散之剂也。二者均是项背强，而发散又有轻重者。盖发热汗出恶风者，为表虚，表虚者可解肌。无汗恶风者为表实，表实者可发汗。是以为治不同也。桂枝加葛根汤方是桂枝加麻黄、葛根，又葛根汤方亦是。[16p]

    Theory of Ming
    (By Jin Cheng Wu Ji)

    Stiff Neck

    In cases of cold damage causing stiff neck, how can we clarify it? The Taiyang channel begins at the inner canthus of the eye, crosses over the top of the head, enters the brain, then exits down the neck, traveling along the shoulder and arm, and internally alongside the spine, reaching the waist. The classic text states: "In Taiyang disease, there is stiffness and pain in the head and neck accompanied by aversion to cold." When the Taiyang channel is affected by wind and cold, the meridians become obstructed, resulting in tension in the neck and stiffness in the nape. When there is stiffness and urgency in the neck from cold damage, this indicates a Taiyang exterior syndrome; it should definitely be treated by dispersing and resolving it. In Taiyang disease, if there is stiffness in the neck and back along with sweating and aversion to wind, Gui Zhi Jia Ge Gen Tang is the main remedy. If there is stiffness in the neck and back without sweating and with aversion to wind, Ge Gen Tang is the main remedy. Both are dispersing agents. Both cases present with stiffness in the neck and back, yet their dispersal has variations in severity. The case with fever, sweating, and aversion to wind suggests an exterior deficiency; the exterior deficiency can be resolved by relaxing the muscles. The case without sweating and with aversion to wind indicates an exterior excess; in this case, we can induce sweating. Hence, the treatments differ. The formula Gui Zhi Jia Ge Gen Tang consists of Gui Zhi combined with Ma Huang and Ge Gen, while Ge Gen Tang is different.[16p]

    桂枝汤中加麻黄、葛根，深详究之，无汗恶风为表实，正可发汗，则于桂枝汤中，加麻黄、葛根为当矣。汗出恶风为表虚，表虚者可解肌，恐是桂枝汤中，但加葛根而不加麻黄也。八，音殊，引颈之貌。八，短羽鸟也。短羽之鸟不能飞腾，动则先伸引其头耳。项背强者，动亦如之，非若几按之几而偃屈也。太阳伤寒项背强，其或太阳中风加之寒湿而成。痉者，亦项强也。经曰：病者身热足寒，颈项强急，恶寒，时头热，面赤，目赤，独头面动动　原缺，据《金匮》痉湿暍病脉证第二改。摇，卒口噤背反张者，痉病也。《金匮要略》曰：太阳病，其证项背强八八然，脉反沉迟者，此为痉，桂枝加(艹舌)蒌汤主之。虽项背强，然太阳病表证悉当发散。又有结胸病者，项亦强如柔痉状，下之则和，宜大陷胸丸主之。临病之际，审其表里，可汗可下，随证投汤，则万全矣。[17p]

    In Gui Zhi Decoction, when Ma Huang and Ge Gen are added, upon detailed examination, if there are no sweat and aversion to wind, this indicates a true excess condition, thus it is appropriate to add Ma Huang and Ge Gen to Gui Zhi Decoction to promote sweating. If sweating is present with aversion to wind, this is a sign of exterior deficiency; in cases of exterior deficiency, one can release the muscles, and it is likely that only Ge Gen should be added to Gui Zhi Decoction without Ma Huang.

    The term "Ba" refers to a distinctive appearance of raising the neck. "Ba" also refers to a short-feathered bird. A short-feathered bird cannot soar and when it moves, it first stretches and raises its head and ears. Those with strong neck and back move in the same manner, unlike those who bend down weakly. In cases of Tai Yang injury with stiff neck and back, this may be due to a combination of Tai Yang wind and cold damp, resulting in stiffness. Spasms are also linked to neck stiffness.

    The classics state: A patient with fever and cold feet, stiff and urgent neck, aversion to cold, occasional fever in the head, red face, and red eyes presents with dynamic head and face movements. The original text is lacking; according to the "Jin Gui," for the symptoms of spasms from damp heat, the pulse changes in the second section may be altered. "Yao" refers to the phenomenon of suddenly closing the mouth and arching the back, indicative of spasms. The "Jin Gui Yao Lue" states that in Tai Yang conditions, if there is neck and back stiffness and the pulse feels deep and slow, this indicates spasms, and Gui Zhi plus (herb) Lou Decoction is the treatment.

    Even with neck and back stiffness, the exterior symptoms in Tai Yang conditions should be completely dispersible. There is also the condition of chest binding, where the neck is similarly stiff as in spasms. In such cases, if purged, it will harmonize, and Da Xianxiong Wan should be employed. When faced with illness, carefully analyze the exterior and interior conditions; treatments may involve sweating or purging according to the symptoms, and then the treatment will be thorough.[17p]
