    　　　　　项软

    　　小儿因风颈软，头不得正，或去前，或去后，宜用天柱天柱　指天柱丸，见本门方中。、五加皮散；风热项软，合用凉肝丸。
    　　　　活法机要 【元　张洁古】[18p]

    Medical Effectiveness of the World

    Soft Neck

    For children whose necks become soft due to wind, causing their heads to tilt forward or backward, it is advisable to use Tianzhu Pill and Wujia Pi Powder; if the soft neck is caused by wind-heat, combined use of Cool Liver Pill is recommended.[18p]

    　　　　　瘰疬

    　　夫瘰疬者，结核是也。或在耳后、或在耳前、或在耳下连及颐颔，或在颈下连缺盆，皆谓之瘰疬。或在胸及胸之侧，或在两胁，皆谓之马刀。手足少阳主之。　　结核耳前后有之，或耳下颔下有之，皆瘰疬也。桑椹二斗，极熟黑色者，以布袋取自然汁，不犯铜铁，以文武火慢熬，作薄膏子，每日百沸汤点一匙，食后，日三服。
    　　　　儒门事亲 【元　张从政】

    　　　　　瘰疬

    　　夫人头目有疮肿瘰疬，及胸臆胠胁之间，或有疮痂肿核不消，及有脓水不止，可用沧盐一二两，炒过，以长流水一大碗煎，放温，作三五次顿服讫，候不多时，于咽喉中探引，吐涎二三升；后服和血通经之药，如玉烛散、四物汤之类是也。《内经》曰：咸味涌泄为阴。涌者吐也，泄者泻也。《铜人》曰：少阳起于目锐眦，行耳后，下胁肋，过期门。瘰疬结核马刀挟瘿，是少阳胆经多气少血之病也。
    　　　　东垣十书 【元　李杲】[19p]

    Lymphadenitis

    Lymphadenitis refers to tuberculous swellings. It may appear behind the ear, in front of the ear, below the ear extending to the jaw, or beneath the neck connecting to the collarbone; all of these are termed lymphadenitis. If it occurs on the chest or its sides, or on both sides of the ribcage, it is referred to as "horse blade." The hand and foot Shaoyang channels govern it. Tuberculous swellings may exist in front of and behind the ear, or beneath the ear and jaw; all are considered lymphadenitis. Use two dou (a unit of measure) of fully ripe dark mulberries, extract the natural juice using a cloth bag without touching copper or iron, and boil it slowly over gentle fire to make a thin ointment. Take one spoonful of this each time with boiling soup after meals, three times a day.

    Ritual of Filial Piety (by Zhang Congzheng, Yuan Dynasty)

    Lymphadenitis

    If there are sores or swellings on the head, or between the chest and ribs, or if there are scabs and swellings that do not disperse, or if there is persistent pus and fluid, one may use one to two ounces of salt treated in a pan, boil it with a large bowl of flowing water until warm, and take it in three to five doses. After a short while, one can probe the throat, producing two to three liters of saliva; afterward, take medications that invigorate the blood and regulate menstruation, such as Yuzhu Powder or Siwu Decoction. The Inner Canon states: "Salty flavor promotes secretion and is associated with Yin." To "secrete" means to expel, and to "release" means to purge. The "Bronze Man" text states: "Shaoyang begins at the eyes, travels behind the ears, descends to the sides of the ribs, and passes the phase gate." Lymphadenitis and tuberculous swellings mixed with goiter is a disorder of the Shaoyang gallbladder channel characterized by excess Qi and deficiency of blood.

    Ten Treatises of Dongyuan (by Li Gao, Yuan Dynasty)[19p]

    　　　　　马刀瘰疬

    　　耳下至缺盆，或至肩上，生疮坚硬如石，动之无根者，名马刀疮，从手足少阳经中来也。或生两胁，或已流脓作疮，或未破，连翘散坚汤并皆治之。　　瘰疬马刀，将先出一疮，用四楞铁环定住，不令出移，破作口子，以油纸捻纴之，勿令合了，以绝其疮之源，其效至速。如疮不破，或病人不肯破，更以药涂之，二日一易之，以龙泉散主之。
    　　　　丹溪心法 【元　朱震亨】

    　　　　　瘰疬结核瘿气

    　　夫瘰疬初起，必起于少阳经；不守禁戒，必延及阳明经。大抵食味之厚，郁气之积，曰毒、曰风、曰热，皆此三端招引变换，须分虚实。彼实者固易治，自非痛断厚味与发气之物，虽易亦难，殊为可虑。以其属胆经，主决断，有相火，而且气多血少。妇人见此，若月经行，不作寒热，可生；稍久转为潮热，其证危矣。自非断欲绝虑食淡，虽神圣不可治也。　　瘰疬属血气痰热，以牡蛎煅过为末，元参捣膏为丸。[20p]

    Horse Knife Sores

    From below the ear to the collarbone, or extending to the shoulder, sores appear hard as stone, and when moved do not have a root; this is called horse knife sores, coming from the lesser yang meridian of the hands and feet. They may appear on both sides of the lower ribs; some may have already become pus-filled sores, and some may not have ruptured yet. The remedies include Lonicera dispersing hard decoction.

    Horse knife sores typically start with the emergence of one sore. Use a four-cornered iron ring to secure it in place, preventing it from moving, and create an opening in it, then cover it with oil paper twisted into a wick, ensuring it does not heal over, thereby cutting off the source of the sore, and the effect is swift. If the sore does not rupture, or if the patient is unwilling to rupture it, apply medicine to the sore, changing it every two days, primarily using Longquan powder.

    Danxi's Heart Method 【Yuan, Zhu Zhenheng】

    Scrofula, Tuberculosis, Goiter

    Scrofula initially arises from the lesser yang meridian; if one does not observe dietary restrictions, it will inevitably extend to the yangming meridian. In general, the excessiveness of food flavors and the accumulation of stagnant qi, referred to as toxin, wind, and heat, all stem from these three aspects and must differentiate between deficiency and excess. The excess type is indeed easy to treat; however, unless one completely avoids rich and gas-producing foods, it remains difficult and quite concerning. As it pertains to the gallbladder meridian, it governs decisions, possessing mutual fire with more qi and less blood. For women who experience this during menstruation, if not suffering from cold or heat, they may conceive; but if it lingers, it may turn into tidal heat, which poses a serious risk. Unless one can decisively eliminate thoughts of rich foods, even the divine and holy cannot treat it. Scrofula is associated with blood, qi, phlegm, and heat; using ground oyster shells prepared through calcination as a powder, and元參 (rehu) pounded into paste forms pills.[20p]

    或桑椹黑熟者捣汁熬膏，汤调服；红者晒干为末，汤调服。　　夏枯草大能散结气而有补养血脉之功，能退寒热，虚者尽可倚仗，若实者以行散之药佐之。外施艾灸，亦渐取效。　　结核，或在项、在颈、在臂、在身，如肿毒者，多在皮里膜外，多是痰注作核不散，问其平日好食何物，吐下后用药散核。结核在下颏，二陈汤加酒炒大黄、连翘、桔梗、柴胡；结核在臂，二陈汤加连翘、防风、川芎、酒芩、苍朮、皂角刺、僵蚕、麝香，行太阴、厥阴之积痰，使结核自消，甚捷。　　瘿气须先断厚味。[21p]

    For mulberries that are black and ripe, crush them to extract the juice and boil it down to a paste for taking with soup; for red ones, dry them and grind them into powder for consumption with soup.

    Summer cress can effectively disperse stagnation and nourish the blood vessels, able to expel cold and heat; those who are deficient can rely on it, while those who are more robust should complement it with dispersing medications. Additionally, external application of moxibustion gradually yields results.

    For swellings or lumps, which may occur in the neck, arms, or the body as toxic swellings, these are often beneath the skin surface, typically caused by phlegm forming into lumps that do not disperse. Inquire about the patient's usual diet, and after purging, use medications to disperse the lumps. If a lump is under the chin, use Erchen Decoction with wine-fried rhubarb, forsythia, platycodon, and bupleurum; for a lump in the arm, combine Erchen Decoction with forsythia, saposhnikovia, chuanxiong, wine-fried scutellaria, atractylodes, spiky sophora fruit, silkworm, and musk to mobilize the phlegm of the Taiyin and Jueyin channels, facilitating the resolution of the lumps, which is quite effective.

    For goiter, one must first avoid heavy flavors.[21p]

    　　凡颈下卒结囊，欲成瘿，以海藻一斤，洗去咸，酒浸饮之。
    　　　　外科精义 【元　齐德之】

    　　　　　瘰疬治法

    　　夫瘰疬之病，其名甚多，《巢氏病源》载之三十六种，《千金》、《圣惠》所论瘰疬九漏，总论说有风毒、热毒、气毒之异。瘰疬结核，寒热之殊，其本皆由恚怒气逆，忧思过甚，风热邪气，内搏于肝。盖怒伤肝，肝主筋，故令筋蓄结而肿。其候多生于颈腋之间，结聚成核，初如豆粒，后若梅李核，累累相连，大小无定。初觉憎寒壮热，咽项强痛，肿结不消者，当便服五香连翘汤，或牡蛎大黄汤，疏下三两行，于上贴十香膏、乌犀膏，及用淋溻肿汤、溃毒汤时复淋溻，如此救疗，即得消散。[22p]

    For nodules that form under the neck and threaten to develop into goiter, take one pound of seaweed, wash away the salt, and soak it in wine to drink.

    Treatment for Lymphatic Tumors

    The disease of lymphatic tumors has many names. The "Chao's Disease Sources" records thirty-six types, while the "Thousand Gold" and "Holy Virtue" texts discuss nine types. Generally, it is said to differ due to wind poison, heat poison, or air poison. The lymphatic nodules arise from the contrast of cold and heat, fundamentally caused by anger and suppressed feelings, excessive worry, and the invasion of wind and heat evils attacking the liver. Anger harms the liver, which governs the tendons, causing them to swell and accumulate. Symptoms often arise in areas between the neck and armpits, forming clusters that start as small as a bean and later grow to the size of a plum pit, interconnected and varying in size. Initially, there may be chills followed by fever, and strong pain in the throat and neck. If the swelling does not subside, one should promptly take Five Spices and Forsythia Decoction or Oysters and Rhubarb Decoction to clear three or two passages. Additionally, apply Ten Fragrance Ointment and Black Rhinoceros Ointment on top, and when employing the Abscess-Draining Decoction or Toxic Soothing Decoction, continue to drain if needed. Following this treatment will lead to resolution.[22p]

    若未消散，可服内消丸或皂角丸之类，渐以求差。若肿结深硬，荏苒日月，不能内消者，久必成脓。若肿高而稍软，其人面色痿黄，皮肤壮热，上蒸脓已成也，可以针决核中，令其溃散则易愈也。治法：如疮法于疮口中，用追毒蚀肉锭子纴之，于上用乌犀十香膏等贴之，及托里之剂和之。经久不差，或愈而复发，或别处自穴，脓水透出，流津不止，肌体羸瘦者，变成九瘘。《内经》曰：陷脉为瘘，留连肉腠，即此病也，可用蒜饼子灸之；然后疮口上用紫金散、翠霞散等，于上纴贴膏药，求瘥。其将护忌慎治疗，用法无造次焉。[23p]

    If it has not dissipated, you may take internal dissolution pills or soapberry pills, gradually seeking improvement. If the swelling is deep and hard, and with the passing of time, it cannot dissolve internally, it will inevitably turn into pus. If the swelling is raised and slightly soft, and the person's complexion is pale yellow, with skin heat and ascending pus already formed, you may puncture and drain the core to facilitate its dispersal and promote healing.

    Treatment method: Similar to treating sores, apply a corrosive and flesh-eroding medication at the sore's opening, and on top apply ointments like black rhinoceros ten fragrance paste. If there is no improvement after a long period, or if it heals only to recur, or if it forms another hole elsewhere, and pus flows continuously and the body becomes emaciated, it may turn into a fistula. The "Inner Classic" states: "A trapped pulse is a fistula, lingering in the flesh's layers; this refers to this condition." You can use garlic cakes for moxibustion; then, apply medicines like purple gold powder and emerald mist powder on the sore, followed by medicinal plasters to seek healing. Take care to treat it with caution and precision, and do not act carelessly in treatment.[23p]

    　　　　证治要诀 【明　戴思恭】

    　　　　　瘰疬

    　　瘰疬之病，皆血气壅结，根在脏腑，多结于颈项之间，累累大小无定，发作寒热，脓血溃漏，或此没而彼起，宜于隔宿用米饮调下桂末、滑石二钱，晨钟动时，进黑白散，必有物如葡萄肉，从小便出其数枚，于肿核则愈；仍常服四七汤加木香或苏子降气汤。其匝颈者，俗名蟠蛇疬，难治。　　先以石菖蒲烂研，盦患处微破，却以猫狸皮连毛烧灰，香油调敷。一味白蔹末，酒调服，多多为上。仍以酒一呷，调白蔹盦患处。掘取生者尤好。或用猪胆内水调雄黄末，敷患处，亦好。[24p]

    Essentials of Diagnosis and Treatment
    (Ming Dynasty - Dai Siguang)

    Luo Li (Scrofula)

    The disease of scrofula is caused by the stagnation and obstruction of blood and Qi, rooted in the organs. It often manifests as lumps on the neck, varying in size, accompanied by intermittent fever and chills, with pus and blood oozing out. Sometimes one lump subsides while another appears. It is advisable to consume rice drink mixed with powdered桂 (cinnamon) and滑石 (talc) of two qian (a unit of measure) every other night. When the morning bell rings, take the black and white powder; it will definitely produce substances resembling grape flesh, which will exit through urine in several pieces, leading to the resolution of the swollen masses. Additionally, regularly take the Siqi Decoction with added 香木 (fragrant wood) or the Suzi Decoction for relieving Qi.

    Those lumps encircling the neck, commonly referred to as "coiling snake scrofula," are difficult to treat. First, grind 石菖蒲 (Acorus calamus) into a paste, slightly break the skin of the affected area, and then burn cat's fur to ash, mixing it with scented oil to apply on the affected place. A powdered white蔹 (a type of medicinal herb), taken mixed with wine, is very effective. It is also beneficial to take a sip of wine and apply the white powder onto the affected area. Utilizing fresh specimens is especially good. Alternatively, mixing water from a pig's gall bladder with powdered雄黄 (realgar) and applying it to the affected area is also effective.[24p]

    　　　　医学纲目 【明　楼英】

    　　　　　瘰疬

    　　初虞世云：瘰疬多生肩项，或赤或白，或沉或浮，初生如豆，久似核，年月浸久，其大如梅，或如鸡卵，排行成列，或生二三，或生六七，俗云蟠蛇疬是也。用性努力，思虑过久，则痰痛赤肿继之，早治为上。　　流注疬，妇人多有之，其性急躁，其气怫郁，其心执着。初生在项，破后脓注四肢，遍体结毒，如梅李状，不疗自破，孔窍相穿，寒热疼痛，或流脓汁，是名流注疬也，又名千岁疮。宜服托里救苦神应丸；如脉有力者，先用追神散下之，却服救苦神应丸。[25p]

    Medical Compendium [Ming Dynasty, Lou Ying]

    Scrofula

    The early description states: Scrofula commonly appears on the shoulders and neck, sometimes red, sometimes white, sometimes hard, sometimes soft. Initially, it resembles a bean; over time, it becomes like a seed. As time passes, it may grow as large as a plum or an egg and can appear in clusters, sometimes in pairs or threes, or as many as six or seven. This is often referred to as "coiled snake scrofula." Symptoms include effort and anxiety, which lead to phlegm, pain, and redness, warranting early treatment as the best option.

    For flowing scrofula, which is more often found in women, its nature is impatient, with stagnant energy and a persistent mind. Initially appearing on the neck, once it breaks, pus flows to the limbs and causes body-wide toxicity, resembling plums or plums. If untreated, it may burst on its own, creating openings through which cold and hot pain occurs or pus flows, thus it is named flowing scrofula, also referred to as "thousand-year sores." It is advisable to take the "Tuo Li Jiu Ku Shen Ying Wan" (Pill to Rescue from Suffering); if the pulse is strong, first use "Zhui Shen San" (Pursuing Spirit Powder) before taking the Rescue Pill.[25p]

    　　单窠疬者，生一个也，发于颈项，最难治，但宜如前药服之，日久自消。或发于顖骨，亦难治。用毒药疗之，勿令浸渍日久。　　莲子疬，一胞裹十数枚，生于项之左右，以手触则能转动，尚可用药治疗。如坚硬挨不动者，乃不可生。憎寒，发热，躁渴，凡遇此证，至难治，虽神圣亦无如之何也已。　　重台疬，生于项颈，或左或右，初则单窠结在上，或在下，重迭见之，是名重台疬。此证药不可疗，不可针灸。若是毒行其肿痛，发渴生痰，万死一生，害人极速。初觉有之，急用小犀角丸、粉金散治之。　　燕窠疬，形似燕窠，不可治。[26p]

    The single-nodule swelling, which appears at the neck, is particularly difficult to treat. It is recommended to use the previously mentioned medicine, and over time it may resolve on its own. If it appears at the occipital bone, it is also hard to treat. Toxic medications can be used, but they should not be allowed to soak for long periods.

    The lotus seed swelling consists of one capsule containing ten or more seeds, growing on either side of the neck. It can be felt and moves when touched, and medication can still be used for treatment. However, if it is hard and immovable, it should not be treated. It is associated with aversion to cold, fever, irritability, and thirst; when these symptoms occur, it is very challenging to treat, even the most skilled cannot do much.

    The heavy terrace swelling appears on the neck, either left or right, initially as a single nodule at the top or bottom, later presenting in layers. This condition cannot be treated with medication or acupuncture. If it causes pain and thirst with phlegm due to toxic progression, it can be life-threatening. At the first sign, urgently use small rhinoceros horn pills or powdered gold for treatment.

    The swallow nest swelling resembles a nest and cannot be treated.[26p]

    　　　　医学入门 【明　李梴】

    　　　　　伤寒项强

    　　项硬而不能左右回顾，太阳初证，表实无汗，葛根汤；表虚有汗，桂枝汤加葛根。若误下，邪气乘虚入里，反结胸而项强又不解，谓之结胸项强。大陷胸汤丸，兼理中丸，或四逆汤服之。所以阴毒初痛，亦有项强，俱以热药治之，正阳散、附子汤是也。　　项强连胁下满者，小柴胡汤。又有风湿项强，痉病项强，不可不辨也。[27p]

    Introduction to Medicine [Ming Dynasty, Li Zhen]

    Stiff Neck due to Typhoid

    If the neck is hard and cannot turn left or right, with initial symptoms of sunstroke, where the exterior is solid and there is no sweating, administer Gegen Decoction; if the exterior is weak with sweating, use Cinnamon Twig Decoction with added Gegen. If wrongly purged, the evil qi can invade internally through the vacuum, causing chest distension and persistence of neck stiffness, termed "distended chest with stiff neck." Use Large Abdominal Distension Pill or Combined Middle Regulation Pill, or take Four Reversal Decoction. Therefore, when Yin Toxicity first causes pain, neck stiffness may also occur; all should be treated with heat-clearing medicines, such as Zhengyang San or Fuzi Decoction. If neck stiffness is accompanied by fullness in the lower ribs, use Minor Chaihu Decoction. Additionally, there are instances of wind-dampness causing neck stiffness and spasmodic neck stiffness, which must not be neglected in diagnosis.[27p]

    　　　　　颈疽对口

    　　六腑阳毒聚于顶，惟太阳膀胱主之，有生于颈后者，疮头向上，疮尾向下，形如蜂窝，乃反证也。焮肿者，急宜托里散加升麻、赤芍、桔梗，防毒攻心。如痰发或流入两肩者，不治。　　有生脑后对口者，名曰夭疽，其状大而色紫黑，不急治，热入渊液，前伤任脉，内熏肝肺，十余日而死。　　焮肿作痛，烦渴好饮冷水，宜解毒汤加天花粉，以除痰火湿热；或黄连消毒散、当归羌活汤、清热消毒饮、活命饮选用。　　肿痛口干作渴，好饮热汤，为肾阳虚火炽，宜托里消毒散、托里益气汤、肾气丸、八味丸。漫肿微痛少食者，补中益气汤。痰多者，托里清中汤。若色黯不溃不敛，为阴精消涸，名脑烁，不治。[28p]

    Neck Sores Treatment Guide

    Yang toxins in the six fu organs gather at the crown, specifically ruled by the Sun Meridian Bladder. If it occurs at the back of the neck, the sore has a head pointing upwards and a tail pointing downwards, resembling a honeycomb, which is a sign of a reversal. In cases of swelling and pain, one should urgently use "Tuo Li San" with the additions of "Sheng Ma," "Chi Shao," and "Jie Geng" to ward off toxins attacking the heart. If phlegm emerges or flows into both shoulders, it is untreatable.

    If a sore arises directly behind the head, it is termed "Yao Ju," appearing large, dark purple or black; urgent treatment is unnecessary. Heat penetrates into the deep fluids, damaging the Ren channel and internally burning the liver and lungs, leading to death within ten days.

    For painful swelling, with thirst and a preference for cold water, one should use detoxifying soup with "Tian Hua Fen" to eliminate phlegm, heat, and dampness; or use "Huang Lian Xiao Du San," "Dang Gui Qiang Huo Tang," "Qing Re Xiao Du Yin," or "Huo Ming Yin" as options.

    For swelling and pain with dry mouth and thirst, with a preference for hot soup, it may indicate kidney Yang deficiency with fiery heat, for which one should use "Tuo Li Xiao Du San," "Tuo Li Yi Qi Tang," "Shen Qi Wan," or "Ba Wei Wan." If there is diffuse swelling, slight pain, and reduced appetite, use "Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang." If there is excessive phlegm, use "Tuo Li Qing Zhong Tang." However, if it appears dark and does not rupture or respond, it indicates depletion of Yin essence, termed "Nao Shuo," and is untreatable.[28p]

    　　　　　瘰疬马刀

    　　生颈前项侧，结核如大豆、如银杏，曰瘰疬；生胸胁腋下，坚硬如石，形如马刀虫，曰马刀。多气少血之病，总皆手足少阳相火所生。盖耳前后与缺盆肩上胛下，属足少阳部分；延及颏项颊车与颐，属足阳明部分；延及胸中中府、云门肺经部分者死。风疬尖而小；热疬焮肿赤色，又名血疬痰疬，推动滑软；气疬圆而动；又有鼠残疬，大小不一。　　无痰不成核。诸瘰初起，实者皆以化痰为主，通用二陈汤加防风、桔梗、黄芩、竹沥。胸紧者，以此探吐尤妙。通经脉必用螌蝥，疏渗小便，以泻心火，古方必效散、立应散是也。[29p]

    Luo Li and Ma Dao

    Luo Li appears at the front side of the neck, forming lumps like large beans or ginkgo nuts; it is called Luo Li. Ma Dao develops in the chest, abdomen, and underarms, hard as stone, resembling the shape of a horse knife worm; it is called Ma Dao. These conditions arise from the pathogen of qi deficiency and blood deficiency, which originates from the lesser yang fire of the hands and feet. The areas before and behind the ears and at the shoulder blades belong to the lower limb lesser yang; extending to the chin, neck, cheeks, and jaw pertains to the upper limb yang brightness; if it extends to the central chest, specifically to the Zhongfu and Yunmen areas of the lung meridian, it results in death.

    Wind-induced lumps are sharp and small; heat-induced lumps are swollen and red, also known as blood lumps or phlegm lumps, which are pushed and soft; qi lumps are round and mobile; there are also mouse remnants, varying in size. Without phlegm, there can be no lumps. For the initial emergence of all luo, those that are solid are primarily treated by transforming phlegm, commonly using the Erchen Decoction with added Fangfeng, Jiegeng, Huangqin, and Zhuli. For chest tightness, this method of inducing vomiting is particularly effective. To open the meridians, the use of scorpions (mandibles) is essential, facilitating urination to drain heart fire; ancient prescriptions like Xiaofengsan and Liying San are indeed effective.[29p]

    但此二药甚峻，服后宜量体调治。体实风热盛者，继以宣热丹服之。体虚者，托里益气汤，或八物汤合二陈汤，多服疮口自敛。又有虚甚者，宜先服健脾药，而后服二散。轻者，只用斑鸡丸便坚。胃盛者白蚕丸，或追脓化毒散、软硬皂子丸。少阳分者，柴胡通经汤；阳明分者，升麻调经汤；少阳阳明二经，二汤合服调之。悞下则犯经禁病禁。　　清肝者，胆与肝合病，则筋累累如贯珠，寒热臖痛，乃肝气动而为病也。当清肝火为主，佐以养血。若寒热止而疮不愈者，乃肝血燥而为病也，当养血为主，佐以清肝。清肝益荣汤、栀子清肝汤、柴胡清肝汤选而用之。[30p]

    However, these two medicines are very strong, and after taking them, one should adjust according to the body's condition. For those with a strong constitution and excess wind-heat, follow with the Heat-expelling Pill. For those with a weak constitution, use the Strengthening the Spleen and Qi Decoction, or the Eight Herbs Decoction combined with the Two Expectorants, taking it frequently to help the sores heal. If very weak, one should first take strengthening the Spleen medicines, and then take the two powders. In milder cases, just using the Dan Chicken Pill will suffice. For those with abundant stomach heat, take the White Silkworm Pill, or the Purging Pus and Detoxifying Powder, or the Soft and Hard Soap Pill. For the Shaoyang stage, use the Chaihu Regulating Qi Decoction; for the Yangming stage, use the Shengma Adjusting Menstrual Decoction; for those involving both the Shaoyang and Yangming channels, combine the two decoctions. If there are excessive downward movements, one should avoid impeding the menstrual cycle or causing other prohibited conditions.

    To clear the liver, if the gallbladder and liver are affected, the tendons will feel tight like stringed pearls, with cold and heat in pain, indicating that the liver qi is disturbed and causing illness. The primary focus should be on clearing liver heat, supplemented by nourishing the blood. If the cold and heat cease but the sores do not heal, it indicates that liver blood is dry and causing illness, so the emphasis should be on nourishing the blood, with liver-clearing as a supplement. Use formulas such as the Clearing Liver and Nourishing Essence Decoction, the Gardenia Clearing Liver Decoction, or the Chaihu Clearing Liver Decoction selectively.[30p]

    　　疮如豆粒，附筋肉，色不变，内热口干，精神倦怠，久不消溃，及肝脉弦紧，肾脉洪数，乃肾水不能生木，以致肝血火动，筋挛，忌用风药燥干。经久烂破，脓血大泄者，脾肾愈亏，火炎于肺，皆宜肾气丸、补中胜毒饼为主，兼服逍遥散加桔梗、麦门冬、元参，以清肺火。多怒，有肝火者，清肝解郁汤；有寒热者，单夏枯草散。肝火旺甚，或近骨处生虫作痒者，芦荟丸、通用猪头丸、海藻散坚丸；外治银右散、蚕茧散、猫蝠散。虚弱者，单夏枯草膏内服，外贴加麻油。　　经年成漏者，初起宜温散风冷，及行肾经湿热邪水，久则大补气血，兼用熏洗平肌塞窍之药。[31p]

    If the sore resembles a bean, attached to muscle, with no color change, accompanied by internal heat, dry mouth, and fatigue, and does not resolve over time, then the liver pulse is tight and the kidney pulse is rapid. This indicates that kidney water cannot nourish wood, leading to liver blood heat movement, muscle cramps, and the prohibition of using wind-drying medications. If there is long-term ulceration with profuse pus and blood leakage, this indicates a further depletion of the spleen and kidneys, and fire inflammation in the lungs. It is advisable to focus on Kidney Qi Pills and Bu Zhong Yi Qi Pills, along with Xiao Yao San added with radix platycodi, Ophiopogon japonicus, and Scrophularia, to clear lung fire. For those who are easily angered with liver fire, use Qing Gan Jie Yu Decoction; if there are cold and heat symptoms, use Dan Xia Ku Cao San. If the liver fire is very strong, or if there is itching near the bones due to worms, use Aloe Pills, the commonly used Pig Head Pills, or Seaweed Harden Pills; externally treat with Yin You San, Silkworm Cocoon Powder, or Cat Bat Powder. For the weak, use Dan Xia Ku Cao Ointment internally and apply with sesame oil externally. For those who have developed a chronic leakage, initially warm and disperse wind-cold, and address damp heat from the kidney channel; over time, greatly supplement Qi and blood, and use fumigation and washing medications to smooth the skin and clear the orifices.[31p]

    古方白蛇散治瘰疬成漏，以其有牵牛，能利肾经恶水，免致淋漓穿穴，但利后当量体调治，痛节酒色财气。　　女人经调及经闭无潮热者可治，经闭有潮热或咳者死。古方用玉烛散治瘰疬和血通经，服之自消，日进一服，七八日见效。便不闭者，柴胡通经汤、升麻调经汤。久虚者，加味逍遥散、清肝益荣汤，或用二陈汤合四物汤，加牡蛎、柴胡、黄芩、元参、神曲为末，以桑椹熬膏，捣丸菉豆大，每五十丸，温酒下；或服肾气丸尤妙。　　瘰疬，疡证之标也，故痨瘵类有曰：腹中有块，颈上有核，最为难治，况成溃漏，而又清金降火，滋肾健脾，病人若不清心淡口，则潮汗渴泻，恶证蜂起，其可生乎？但视其目内，赤脉贯瞳人有几条，则知其几年死。面色晄白，金克木，脉洪大，为元气虚败，俱为不治。故曰实者可治，虚者可虑。[32p]

    The ancient method known as the White Snake Powder treats scrofula that has developed into an ulcer. It contains Qian Niu, which can benefit the kidney meridian by eliminating harmful moisture and preventing excessive drainage through openings. However, it must be adjusted according to the individual's condition, avoiding excessive wine, lust, and greed.

    For women with irregular menstruation or amenorrhea without tidal fever, treatment is possible, but if there is tidal fever or coughing with amenorrhea, it is often fatal. The ancient method employs the Jade Candle Powder to treat scrofula and regulate blood flow. Taking it will lead to self-healing, with a daily dose showing results within seven to eight days. For those not experiencing amenorrhea, the Chai Hu Decoction for Menstrual Regulation and the Sheng Ma Decoction for Menstrual Adjustment are recommended. For long-standing deficiencies, add the Modified Xiao Yao Powder or the Qing Gan Yi Rong Decoction, or use the Er Chen Decoction combined with the Si Wu Decoction, adding ingredients like oyster shell, Chai Hu, Huang Qin, Yuan Shen, and Shen Qu, ground into a powder, mixed with mulberry syrup to form pills the size of mung beans. Take fifty pills with warm wine, or opt for the Shen Qi Pills for even better results.

    Scrofula is a hallmark of ulcerative diseases, and thus diseases of the lungs indicate that if there are lumps in the abdomen or nodes on the neck, they are particularly difficult to treat, especially when they develop into ulcers. One must clear the heat and nourish the kidney and spleen. If a patient does not maintain a calm mind and light diet, they risk profuse sweating, thirst, and diarrhea, leading to severe complications. By observing the eyes, if several red veins cross the pupil, one can estimate the years until death. If the complexion is pale, with a strong pulse, it indicates profound deficiency of vital energy and is considered untreatable. Hence, it is said that real excess can be treated, but true deficiency should be approached with caution.[32p]

    　　　　　痰核

    　　颈项生核，不红不痛，不作脓，推之则动，乃痰聚不散也，不可悞用瘰疬药，治宜二陈汤加大黄、连翘、柴胡、桔梗。体薄者二陈汤加桔梗、黄芩、元参、麦门冬及防风少许，入竹沥，多服自消。如耳后与项间，各有一块者，含化丹。　　臂核或作微痛者，以内无脓，故外虽肿不红，或生背膊皆然。宜陈皮、半夏、茯苓、防风、酒芩各一钱，连翘二钱，皂角刺一钱半，川芎、苍朮各五分，甘草三分，水煎服。　　凡遍身有块，多是痰注，但在上体多兼风热，在下体多兼湿热，宜加味小胃丹、竹沥达痰丸，量体虚实服之；通用海带丸。[33p]

    Phlegm Nodules

    Nodules in the neck are neither red nor painful, do not form pus, and can be moved when pushed; these are phlegm accumulations that do not disperse. It is inappropriate to hastily use medications for scrofula. Treatment should be a modified Erchen Decoction with Dahuang (rhubarb), Lianqiao (forsythia), Chaihu (bulbous chive), and Jiegeng (platycodon). For those with a thin physique, modify the Erchen Decoction by adding Jiegeng, Huangqin (scutellaria), Yuanshen (root of the Chinese peony), Mai Men Dong (ophiopogon), and a little Fangfeng (siler), along with Zhuli (bamboo juice); frequent intake helps dissolve the nodules.

    If there are lumps behind the ears or between the neck, each with one nodule, they should be dissolved with a Dan (pills). Nodules in the arms, or causing slight pain, are due to the absence of pus; thus, although swollen, they are not red. This also applies to those appearing on the back or shoulders. The remedy should include Chenpi (dried tangerine peel), Banxia (pinellia), Fuling (poria), Fangfeng (siler), and Jiuqin (wine-forged forsythia), each a qian (a unit of weight), with Lianqiao (forsythia) two qians, and Zaojiao (soapberry) one and a half qians, along with Chuanxiong (ligusticum) and Cangzhu (atractylodes) each five fen (a smaller unit of weight), and Gancao (licorice) three fen, brewed in water for consumption.

    Generally, if there are lumps all over the body, they are often due to phlegm accumulation. In the upper body, they often accompany wind-heat, while in the lower body, they usually accompany damp-heat. It is advisable to add flavors to Xiaowei Decoction and use Zhuli (bamboo juice) to move phlegm, adjusting the dosage according to one's condition of deficiency or excess; Kelp Pills are also commonly used.[33p]

    　　　　　瘿

    　　瘿皆痰与气相结而成。筋脉呈露曰筋瘿，赤脉交络曰血瘿，皮色不变曰肉瘿，随忧愁消长曰气瘿，坚硬不可移曰石瘿，其名有五者此也。内应五脏，治与瘤同。　　形似樱桃，一边纵大似槌而垂，皮宽不急，原因忧患所生，故又名瘿气，今之所谓影囊者似也。忧恚耗伤心肺，故多着颈项及肩，劳欲邪气，乘经之虚而作。　　或软或硬，无痛无痒，体实者海藻散坚丸、海带丸；痰火盛者，舐掌散、神效开结散。此皆化痰行气破坚之剂，久虚者不可妄服。　　通用：初起者，十六味流气饮、单蜘蛛方；稍久者，蜡矾丸，常服自然缩小。消磨：外敷南星膏。切不可轻用刀针决破，破则脓血崩溃，渗漏无已，必至杀人。[34p]

    Goiter

    Goiter is formed by the combination of phlegm and qi. When tendons and veins are visible, it is called tendon goiter; when there are interwoven red veins, it is blood goiter; when the skin color remains unchanged, it is flesh goiter; when it fluctuates with worries and sorrows, it is qi goiter; and when it is hard and immovable, it is stone goiter. These five names correspond to different types. It relates to the five organs and is treated similarly to tumors.

    Its shape resembles a cherry, with one side larger and drooping like a hammer, and the skin is wide and not tight. It arises from worries and troubles, hence it is also called goiter qi; it resembles what is now referred to as a shadow sac. Worries and anger deplete the heart and lungs, so it often appears on the neck and shoulders. Evil qi from exertion takes advantage of the body's deficiencies to manifest.

    It can be either soft or hard, and there is no pain or itchiness. For solid types, use Hai Zao San Jian Wan or Hai Dai Wan; for abundant phlegm and fire, use Shi Zhang San or Shen Xiao Kai Jie San. These are all remedies to transform phlegm, move qi, and break down hardness, and those who have been ill for a long time should not take them rashly.

    Common treatments: for those starting out, use Shi Liu Wei Liu Qi Yin or Dan Zhizhu Fang; for those with a longer duration, use La Fan Wan, and regular use will naturally reduce the size. To dissolve it, apply Nan Xing Gao externally. One must not lightly use knives or needles to puncture it, as this would lead to the burst of pus and blood, causing uncontrollable seepage that inevitably leads to death.[34p]

    　　　　伤寒六书 【明　陶华】

    　　　　　项强

    　　项背强者，太阳表邪也，发散则解。结胸项强，有下之证。寒湿项强，成痉。　　太阳病项强，无汗恶风为表实，葛根汤。项背强，发热有汗恶风为表虚，桂枝加葛根汤。误下太阴，结胸项强，太陷胸丸。一法，寒实甚者，兼与四逆汤。　　项强胁下满，身热恶风，手足汗而渴，小柴胡汤。　　阴毒初得，病项背强，咽痛，心腹痛，短气，厥逆，吐利，身如被杖，附子汤、阴毒甘草汤、正阳丹。天行复作热，至晚则腰痛，头项强，身重，葛根生姜豉汤。[35p]

    Shang Han Liu Shu [Ming, Tao Hua]

    Stiffness of the Neck

    Stiffness of the neck and back indicates external evil affecting the Taiyang channel; dispersing it will lead to resolution. If there is chest congestion with neck stiffness, it suggests interior issues. Cold and damp leading to neck stiffness causes cramping. In Taiyang disease, if neck stiffness is accompanied by absence of sweat and aversion to wind, it indicates an excess condition, treated with Ge Gen Tang. If stiffness of the neck and back is present with fever, sweating, and aversion to wind, it suggests a deficiency condition, treated with Gui Zhi Jia Ge Gen Tang.

    If the Taiyin has been mistaken for treatment, leading to chest congestion and neck stiffness, use Tai Xian Xiao Wan. For severe cold excess, combine with Si Ni Tang. When there is neck stiffness with fullness under the ribs, body heat, aversion to wind, and sweating in the hands and feet, use Xiao Chai Hu Tang.

    When initially afflicted by a Yin toxin presenting with neck stiffness, sore throat, abdominal pain, shortness of breath, reversed flow, vomiting, diarrhea, and a body feeling as though beaten, use Fu Zi Tang, Yin Du Gan Cao Tang, or Zheng Yang Dan. If the seasonal heat reoccurs, leading to evening waist pain, neck stiffness, and body heaviness, use Ge Gen Sheng Jiang Chi Tang.[35p]

    　　　　薛氏医案 【明　薛己】

    　　　　　瘰疬

    　　夫瘰疬之病，属三焦肝胆二经，怒火风热血燥；或肝肾二经，精血亏损，虚火内动；或恚怒气逆，忧思过甚，风热邪气，内搏于肝。盖怒伤肝，肝主筋，肝受病，则筋累累然如贯珠也。其候多生于耳前后项腋间，结聚成核，初觉憎寒恶热，咽项强痛。若寒热臖痛者，此肝火风热而气病也，用小柴胡汤以清肝火，并服加味四物汤以养肝血。若寒热既止而核不消散者，此肝经火燥而血病也，用加味逍遥散以清肝火，六味地黄丸以生肾水。[36p]

    Case Study on Scrofula
    By Xue Ji, Ming Dynasty

    Scrofula is a disease associated with the Sanjiao (Triple Burner), liver and gallbladder meridians, characterized by anger, heat, dryness of the blood, or linked to the liver and kidney meridians with depletion of essence and blood, leading to internal heat. It may also arise from excessive anger, anxiety, and overthinking, combined with pathogenic heat and wind that impede the liver. Anger harms the liver, which governs the muscles; when the liver is affected, the muscles become knotted and tense. Symptoms often appear in front of and behind the ears, as well as in the armpits, forming lumps. Initially, there is a dislike of cold and a hatred of heat, with pain in the throat and neck. If there is a cold-heat sensation with pain, this indicates heat in the liver and a related qi condition; for treatment, use Xiao Chai Hu Decoction to clear liver heat, along with Jia Wei Si Wu Decoction to nourish liver blood. If the cold and heat have subsided but the lumps persist, it indicates dryness and heat in the liver meridian leading to blood issues; in this case, use Jia Wei Xiao Yao San to clear liver heat and Liu Wei Di Huang Wan to replenish kidney water.[36p]

    若肿高而稍软，面色痿黄，皮肤壮热，脓已成也，可用针以决之，及服托里之剂。若经久不愈，或愈而复发，脓水淋漓，肌体羸瘦者，必纯补之剂，庶可收敛，否则变成九瘘。《内经》曰：陷脉为瘘，留连肉腠，即此病也。外用豆豉饼、琥珀膏，以驱散寒邪，补接阳气；内服补中益气汤六味丸，以滋肾水，培肝木，健脾土，亦有可愈者。大抵肝胆部分结核，不问大小，其脉左关弦紧，左尺洪数者，乃肾水不能生肝木，以致肝火燥而筋挛，须用前药以滋化源，是治其本也。《外台秘要》云：肝肾虚热则生疬。[37p]

    If there is swelling that is high and slightly soft, with a pale yellow complexion, hot skin, and pus has formed, one may use a needle to drain it and take a medicinal formula for resolution. If it has not healed after a long time, or if it heals but recurs, with pus flowing freely and the body becoming emaciated, one must use purely restorative medicines to consolidate; otherwise, it may turn into a complex condition like fistulas. The "Inner Canon" states: a sinking pulse is indicative of a fistula, lingering between the flesh layers, which is this disease. Externally apply soybean cakes and amber ointment to dispel cold evils and replenish Yang energy; internally, take the "Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction" or Six Flavor Pill to nourish kidney water, strengthen liver wood, and fortify spleen earth, which may also lead to healing. Generally, tuberculosis in the liver and gallbladder, regardless of size, is indicated by a tight pulse at the left guan and a rapid pulse at the left chi, suggesting that kidney water cannot generate liver wood, leading to liver fire drying and muscle cramps. One must use preceding medicines to nourish the source and treat the root of the problem. The "Secret Essentials of the Outer Repository" states: deficiency heat in the liver and kidney can cause sores.[37p]

    《病机》云：瘰疬不系膏粱丹毒火热之变，因虚劳气郁所致，止宜补形气调经脉，其疮自消散，盖不特汗之下之而已也。其不详脉证经络受病之异者，下之则犯经禁病禁，虚虚之祸，如指诸掌。若脉洪大，元气虚败为不治；若面晄白，为金克木亦不治；若眼内赤脉贯瞳人，见几条则几年死。使不从本而治，妄用伐肝之剂则悞矣。盖伐肝则脾土先伤，脾伤则损五脏之源矣，可不慎哉。　　焮肿脉沉数者，邪气实也，宜泄之。肿痛憎寒发热或拘急者，邪在表也，宜发散。因怒结核或肿痛，或发热者，宜疏肝行气。肿痛浮脉数者，祛风清热。[38p]

    The text "Bing Ji" states: Tuberculosis is not caused by a transformation of hot conditions from rich foods or fire toxins, but rather arises from deficiencies and stagnation of qi. It is appropriate to nourish the body, boost qi, and regulate the meridians, allowing the sores to dissipate naturally; this is achieved not only by sweating them out. If pulse and symptom patterns are not precisely identified, recklessly purging may offend the meridians and lead to disaster—especially if the pulse is strong and large, indicating a deficiency of the original qi, which signifies incurability; if the face is pale, it shows metal restraining wood and also indicates no cure; if there are red veins seen in the eyes, especially several, it suggests imminent death in a few years. To treat without addressing the root causes and arbitrarily using liver-clearing medications is misguided. For clearing the liver can first harm the spleen; if the spleen is damaged, it undermines the source of the five organs, which must be approached with caution.

    For a burning and swollen pulse that is deep and rapid, it indicates strong evil qi, and thus, should be drained. If there is swelling and pain with aversion to cold, fever, or rigidity, the evil resides on the surface and should be released. If anger leads to swelling or pain, or fever, it is advisable to soothe the liver and promote qi flow. For swelling, pain, and a floating, rapid pulse, one should dispel wind and clear heat.[38p]

    脉濇者补血为主，脉弱者补气为主，肿硬不溃者补气血为主。抑郁所致者，解郁结调气血。溃后不敛者，属气血俱虚，宜大补。虚劳所致者，补之。因有核而不敛者，腐而补之。脉实而不敛或不消者，下之。　　张氏云：室女月水久不行，切不可用青蒿等凉剂。医家多以为室女血热，故以凉药解之。殊不知血得热则行，冷则凝，《养生必用方》言之甚详。此说大有理，不可不知。若经候微少，渐渐不通，手足骨肉烦疼，日渐羸瘦，渐生潮热，其脉微数，此由阴虚血弱，阳往乘之，小水不能灭盛火，火逼水涸，亡津液，当养血益阴，慎毋以毒药通之，宜柏子仁丸、泽兰丸。[39p]

    For a weak pulse, focus on nourishing the blood; for a feeble pulse, prioritize energy replenishment; for swollen and hard conditions that do not resolve, center on tonifying both qi and blood. In cases caused by depression, aim to soothe the stagnation and regulate qi and blood. If there is persistent ulceration that does not close, this indicates a deficiency in both qi and blood, warranting a substantial replenishment. If there is a condition where there is a kernel that does not resolve, it should be treated with nourishment and restoration. For a strong pulse that does not resolve or diminish, purgation is necessary.

    Zhang states: If a maiden's menstrual cycle is long overdue, never use cooling agents such as Qinghao. Many practitioners mistakenly think the maiden has excessive heat in the blood, hence employing cooling medicines. Little do they know that heat causes blood to flow, while cold leads to stagnation, as emphasized in "Essential Prescriptions for Health." This reasoning is very significant and should not be overlooked.

    If the menstrual symptoms are slightly present, gradually become obstructed, accompanied by pain in the limbs and bones, gradual emaciation, and the emergence of tidal fevers with a weak and rapid pulse, this denotes yin deficiency and weak blood, allowing yang to prevail. Small water cannot extinguish the overwhelming fire; heat forces water to dry up, leading to the loss of body fluids. One should nourish the blood and enhance yin, and be cautious not to use toxic substances for resolution. The appropriate remedies would be Bai Zi Ren Wan and Ze Lan Wan.[39p]

    　　　　证治准绳 【明　王肯堂】

    　　　　　颈项强痛

    　　颈项强急之证，多由邪客三阳经也。寒搏则筋急，风搏则筋弛；左多属血，右多属痰。　　颈项强急，发热恶寒，脉浮而紧，此风寒客三阳经也，宜驱邪汤。　　颈项强急，动则微痛，脉弦而数实，右为甚，作痰热客三阳经治，宜消风豁痰汤。　　颈项强急，动则微痛，脉弦而濇，左为甚，作血虚邪客太阳阳明经治，宜疏风滋血汤。　　颈项强急，寒热往来，或呕吐，或胁痛，宜小柴胡汤、升麻防荆汤。　　颈项强急，腰似折，项似拔，加味胜湿汤。　　精神短少，不睡，项筋肿急难伸，禁甘温，宜苦寒，养神汤主之。　　《本事方》椒附散，治肾气上攻，项背不能转侧，于虚寒者为宜。　　颈痛非是风邪，即是气挫　亦有落枕而成痛者，并宜和气饮，食后服。按人多有挫闪，及久坐并失枕而致项强不可转移者，皆由肾虚不能生肝，肝虚无以养筋，故机关不利，宜六味地黄丸常服。[40p]

    Zheng Zhi Zhun Sheng 【Ming Dynasty - Wang Kengtang】

    Stiffness and Pain in the Neck

    The symptoms of stiffness and pain in the neck are often caused by external pathogenic factors invading the three Yang meridians. Cold causes the tendons to tighten, while wind allows them to relax; pain on the left side is often related to blood, while pain on the right is usually associated with phlegm. Stiffness and pain in the neck, accompanied by fever and aversion to cold, with a pulse that is floating and tight, indicate that wind and cold are invading the three Yang meridians, and a dispelling evil decoction is advisable.

    If the neck is stiff and painful with slight movement, and the pulse is wiry and rapid, with greater severity on the right side, it indicates phlegm heat affecting the three Yang meridians, and a decoction to dissipate wind and resolve phlegm should be used. If stiffness and pain occur with slight movement, and the pulse is wiry and weak, with greater severity on the left side, it indicates blood deficiency and evil affecting the Taiyang and Yangming meridians, warranting a decoction to disperse wind and nourish blood.

    If the neck is stiff and there are alternating chills and fever, along with symptoms such as vomiting or pain in the flank, Xiao Chai Hu Decoction or Sheng Ma and Fang Jing Decoction is recommended. For severe stiffness, akin to a feeling of breaking in the waist, add a modified Sheng Shi Decoction. If there is a lack of mental energy or inability to sleep, with swollen and tense neck muscle, avoid sweet and warm foods, and a bitter-cold nourishing the spirit decoction is indicated.

    In cases where neck pain is not caused by wind evil, but rather by Qi stagnation, it is also possible for it to result from sleeping improperly, and in such cases, He Qi Decoction should be taken after meals. Many people suffer from trauma, excessive sitting, or improper sleeping position leading to neck stiffness, primarily due to kidney deficiency failing to nourish the liver, resulting in weak liver function unable to support the tendons, which can disrupt the mechanisms of movement; therefore, taking Liu Wei Di Huang Wan regularly is advised.[40p]

    　　　　　瘰疬

    　　结核连续者为瘰疬，形长如蛤者为马刀。一云，瘰疬者结核是也。或在耳后耳前，或在耳下连及颐颔，或在颈下连缺盆，皆谓之瘰疬；或在胸及胸之侧，或在两胁，皆谓之马刀，手足少阳主之。　　《集验》云：夫瘰疬疮者，有风毒、热毒、气毒之异，瘰疬结核寒热之殊，其证皆由忿怒气逆，忧思过甚，风热邪气，内搏于肝。盖怒伤肝，肝主筋，故令筋缩结蓄而肿也。其候多生颈项胸腋之间，结聚成核，初如豆粒，后若梅李，累累相连，大小无定。[41p]

    Lymphadenitis

    The continuous presence of tuberculosis is referred to as lymphadenitis, while projections that resemble elongated clams are known as "horse blades." Some say that lymphadenitis is indeed a manifestation of tuberculosis. It can occur behind or in front of the ear, or below the ear spanning to the jaw, or below the neck extending to the collarbone; all of these are termed lymphadenitis. It may also appear on the chest and its sides, or in the flanks, and is referred to as horse blades, with the Lesser Yang governing these. According to "Jiyuan," lymphadenitis sores result from different types of wind poison, heat poison, and qi poison; the lymphadenitis tumors exhibit varied cold and heat symptoms. These conditions arise from excessive anger and emotional distress, with wind and heat evils attacking the liver. Anger harms the liver, which governs the tendons, causing them to contract, accumulate, and swell. The symptoms often manifest between the neck, chest, and flanks, forming clusters that initially resemble bean-sized lumps and later grow to look like plums or dates, interconnected in varying sizes.[41p]

    初觉憎寒壮热，咽项强痛，肿结不消者，便当服散肿溃坚汤，或五香连翘漏芦汤之类散之。或用牡蛎大黄汤疏利三两行，疮上可用十香膏之类贴之，及诸淋洗敷贴等药治之，庶得消散。若不散，可用内消丸之类消之，或隔蒜灸之，仍断欲息气，薄滋味调理之。不然，恐日久变生寒热咳嗽，而成劳瘵之疾，不可治矣。又有马刀疮，亦生于项腋之间，有类瘰疬，但初起其状如马刀，赤色如火，烧烙极痛，此疮甚猛，宜急治之，不然成危殆也，临证辨之。[42p]

    When you first feel a dislike for cold and a strong heat, with pain in the throat and swelling that does not subside, you should take a decoction for dispersing swelling and softening hardness, or similar remedies like Five-Spice Lianqiao and Leoru Decoction. You can also use Oysters and Dahuang Decoction to promote bowel movements and relieve symptoms. For sores, you may apply a blend like Ten-Fragrance Ointment, along with various washing and topical treatments to help dissipate the condition. If it does not improve, internal remedies like消内丸 should be used, or moxibustion with garlic can be employed. One should also avoid breathing deeply and consume light, easy-to-digest foods for recovery. Otherwise, fear arises that over time, it may develop into cold and heat cough and lead to a condition like tuberculosis, which would be difficult to treat.

    Additionally, there are horse knife sores, which arise between the neck and armpits resembling scrofula. Initially, they appear like a horse knife, red and fiery, causing extreme burning pain. These sores are very severe and should be treated urgently; otherwise, they may become life-threatening. Differentiate and diagnose correctly in such acute cases.[42p]

    　　　　　治法

    　　治疗次第，初觉憎寒壮热，咽项强痛，肿结不消者，以羌活连翘汤；又宜常服消疬丸；却以棱针刺破出血，以拔毒汤热淋洗，一日洗五七次，针五七次，放蟾酥末少许于针处上，以琥珀膏贴之，更以内消膏贴之，久久自然而消也。如不散者，用铁筒拔毒膏点破，次以下品锭子取去恶肉，可作溃疡治之，用十宣散之类托里。若毒攻心呕吐者，用粉乳托里散发出毒，此要兼针灸法同施。若已溃不愈者，宜益气养荣汤、八物汤加柴胡、地骨皮、夏枯草、附子、贝母，多服取效。凡用锭子药线，必用托里之剂服之。焮赤肿痛，脉沉数者，邪气实也，宜泄之，以化毒消肿和里散加减。肿痛憎寒发热，或拘急，脉浮数者，邪在表也，宜散表，以荆防败毒加减。因怒结核或肿痛或发热者，宜疏肝行气，以小柴胡汤加青皮、青木香、红花、桃仁。肿硬不溃者，宜补气血，以益气养荣汤。抑郁所致者，解郁结调气血，以益气养荣汤。[43p]

    Treatment Method

    For the treatment regimen, if a patient initially experiences chills, intense heat, strong pain in the throat and neck, with swelling that does not subside, use the Qianghuo Lianqiao Decoction. Additionally, regular consumption of the Xiaoyao Wan (Happy Wanderer Pill) is advisable. Furthermore, puncture the area with a needle to draw out blood; use the Baodu Decoction for hot washes, five to seven times a day. Perform needling five to seven times as well, placing a small amount of toad venom powder at the needle site and covering it with amber balm. Over time, this will lead to natural resolution. If it does not recede, use an iron tube to apply the detox ointment, then remove necrotic tissue with a lower-grade medicinal pellet, which can be used for ulcer treatment. Apply ten xuan powder or similar substances for this. If toxins attack the heart causing vomiting, use powdered milk and detoxifying powders. This should be paired with acupuncture methods. If there is an ulcer that does not heal, the Yi Qi Yang Rong Decoction or Ba Shi Wu Decoction with additional Chai Hu, Di Gu Pi, Xia Ku Cao, Fu Zi, and Bei Mu should be taken frequently for efficacy. Whenever using pellet medicines, it is crucial to take along the detoxifying agents.

    For redness, swelling, and pain with a deep, rapid pulse, it indicates substantial pathogenic influence; thus, it should be expelled to transform toxins, reduce swelling, harmonize the interior, and adjust accordingly. If there is swelling, pain, chills, heat, or tension with a floating, rapid pulse, it indicates the evil is at the surface; therefore, disperse the exterior using Jing Fang Bai Du with adjustments. If swelling, pain, or fever arises from anger, promote liver qi and alleviate stagnation using Xiao Chai Hu Decoction with Qing Pi, Qing Mu Xiang, Hong Hua, and Tao Ren added. If the swelling is hard and unulcerated, tonify qi and blood with Yi Qi Yang Rong Decoction. If it stems from repression, resolve stagnation and regulate qi and blood with Yi Qi Yang Rong Decoction.[43p]

    溃后不敛者，属气血俱虚，宜大补，以益气养荣汤，次用十全大补汤加香附子、贝母、远志。虚劳所致者宜补之，先以补中益气汤，次以益气养荣汤加减。因有核溃而不敛者，腐而兼补，以针头腐之，以益气养荣汤补之。脉实而不敛或不消者，下之以羌活连翘汤。肿痛发寒热大便秘，以羌活连翘汤，次以神仙活命饮。耳下结核肿痛，发寒热，宜荆防败毒散；表证悉退，以散肿溃坚汤。溃后核不腐，以益气养荣汤，更敷针头散腐之。肿硬久不消，亦不作脓，服散坚败毒药不应，宜灸肘尖、肩尖，服益气养荣汤而消。气血壮实之人，脉沉实而大者，亦不觉损，方可进必效散、遇仙无比丸下其毒；若其毒一下，即止二药，更服益气养荣汤调理。疮口不敛，宜用豆豉饼灸之，以琥珀膏、十香膏贴之。针后发热，烦躁作渴，脉大无力，此血虚也，宜以当归补血汤，次以圣愈汤，再以八物汤加贝母、远志。劳心过度，颈肿发热，服败毒药愈甚，以补中益气数剂而消。[44p]

    After a rupture that does not close, it indicates both qi and blood are deficient. It is advisable to nourish with a great restorative formula, using Benefit Qi and Nourish Essence Decoction, followed by Ten Complete Major Restorative Decoction with added Cyperus and Fritillaria, as well as Polygala. For cases caused by deficiency and overstrain, it is necessary to support first with the Supplement Middle and Benefit Qi Decoction, then follow with Benefit Qi and Nourish Essence Decoction with adjustments. When there is a rupture that does not heal, due to decay combined with the need for nourishment, use a needle to treat the decay and supplement with the Benefit Qi and Nourish Essence Decoction. If the pulse is strong and does not close or resolve, treat with Qianghuo Lianqiao Decoction. For swelling and pain accompanied by chills and fever and constipation, use Qianghuo Lianqiao Decoction, followed by the Divine Immortal Life-Saving Drink. For submandibular swollen and painful lymph nodes with chills and fever, use Jingfang Baituo Powder; once the exterior condition subsides, use the Swelling Dispersal and Hardening Dissolution Decoction. If after a rupture the mass does not decay, apply the Benefit Qi and Nourish Essence Decoction, while also using the needle to disperse the decay. If the swelling is hard and long-lasting without suppuration, and not responding to dispersing hardening Baituo medicine, it is advisable to moxibust the tip of the elbow and shoulder, while taking the Benefit Qi and Nourish Essence Decoction for resolution. For those with robust qi and blood, if the pulse is deep, full, and large without feeling diminished, one can take Biuxiao San and Wuxian Wubi Pill to eliminate toxins. If the toxin responds, stop these two medicines and continue with the Benefit Qi and Nourish Essence Decoction for regulation. If the wound edges do not close, it is appropriate to apply a bean curd cake for moxibustion and use amber ointment and Ten Fragrance Ointment as a dressing. If there is fever after needling, restlessness, and thirst with a large and weak pulse, it indicates blood deficiency; one should use the Danggui Blood Nourishment Decoction, then follow with Shengyu Decoction, and additionally Bawei Decoction with Fritillaria and Polygala. For those overexerted mentally, presenting heat and swelling in the neck, if toxin treatments worsen the condition, it is necessary to take several doses of Supplement Middle and Benefit Qi to resolve the issue.[44p]

    　　　　　百脉疽

    　　《鬼遗》云：百脉疽肿起，环颈项疼痛，身体大热，不敢动止，悁悁不能食，此有大畏恐骇，上气咳嗽，其发引耳，不可以肿，十五日可刺导引，不刺导引见血，八十日必死。
    　　　　　颈痈

    　　或问：颈上生痈疽何如？曰：是颈痈也，属手少阳三焦经郁火积愤惊惶所致。初觉即隔蒜灸，服活命饮加元参、桔梗、升麻及胜金丹、夺命丹汗之；壮实者一粒金丹下之；老弱者十全大补汤、人参养荣汤。若溃而不敛，烦躁胀满，小便如淋，呕吐者，死。[45p]

    Bai Mai Ju (Hundred Pulses Abscess)

    The "Gui Yi" states: When the hundred pulses abscess swells, there is pain around the neck, the body feels very hot, and one is reluctant to move, with a feeling of heaviness and inability to eat. This indicates a great fear and anxiety, with a rising Qi causing cough. The swelling extends to the ears; it should not be punctured. One can perform needling or manipulation after fifteen days. If needling or manipulation results in blood, death is certain within eighty days.

    Neck Abscess

    Someone asked: What to do when an abscess forms on the neck? The answer: This is a neck abscess, resulting from the accumulated heat and anger in the hand Shaoyang Sanjiao channel. As soon as one feels it, use garlic for moxibustion and take "Huo Ming Yin" with added Yuan Shen, Jie Geng, Sheng Ma, as well as "Sheng Jin Dan" and "Duo Ming Dan" for sweating. For robust individuals, a pill of Jin Dan can be taken; for the elderly and weak, use "Shi Quan Da Bu Tang" or "Ren Shen Yang Rong Tang." If it bursts and does not heal, with agitation, bloating, and urination resembling dripping, accompanied by vomiting, it will lead to death.[45p]

    　　　　　项中疽

    　　或问：颈后脑下发疽何如？曰：此即对口疮也，属督脉。阳独盛，气有余，火炎上而发疽也。急服乌金散、胜金丹汗之；壮实者，一粒金丹下之。稍迟，溃出脓水，入风发搐者，难治。有毒邪壅盛鲜血暴涌者，死。毒攻心腹膨胀谵语者，死。此证脓赤肿痛可治，若根大精神昏愦即难治也。量表里虚实而为汗下，内托内消，外用大围药箍住，中点六灰膏之类，破泄其毒，不可走失根脚。若欲流两肩脊者，不可疗也。或云先服追疔夺命汤二贴，后服活血化毒汤。
    　　　　　天柱疽

    　　或问：天柱骨上，极痒入骨，恶心吐逆，肩背拘急何如？曰：此名天柱疽，急隔蒜灸，痒止为度；无蒜，明灸可治。服活命饮加羌活、桔梗。乌金散、胜金丹选用。灸而有泡者吉，无泡者凶。服汗剂得汗可治，无汗难治。若溃烂神昏，呕哕恶心，血不止者死。
    　　　　　杼疽[46p]

    Abscess of the Neck

    Someone asked: What about an abscess that forms under the back of the neck? The answer: This is known as a “mouth sore,” and it is associated with the Governor Vessel. When Yang is overly abundant, and the Qi is excessive, the fire rises and causes the abscess to form. One should urgently take Wujin San and Shengjindan for sweating; for those who are robust, one pellet of Jindan should be taken. If delayed, pus will flow out; if it leads to convulsions due to wind, it is difficult to treat. If there is toxic evil blocking with violent surges of fresh blood, it can lead to death. If the poison attacks the heart and abdomen, causing bloating and delirium, it also results in death. This condition, with red, swollen pain, can be treated; however, if the root is large and spirit is confused, it is difficult to cure. Assess the balance of deficiency and excess to induce sweating and down regulate internally, while using external powerful medicaments to contain it; apply medicinal paste like Liu Huai Gao to break and drain the poison, ensuring the root is not lost. If it spreads to the shoulders and back, do not treat. Some suggest first taking the Pursuing Sore and Life-Depriving Decoction for two applications, followed by the Blood-Activating and Toxic-Cleansing Decoction.

    Tianzhu Abscess

    Some asked: What about an abscess on the Tianzhu bone, causing extreme itchiness to the bone, with nausea and vomiting, and tightness in the shoulders and back? The answer: This is called Tianzhu abscess. Urgently apply garlic moxibustion to relieve the itch; if garlic is unavailable, bright moxibustion can also treat it. Take Lifesaving Decoction with Qiang Huo and Jie Geng added. Select suitable Wujin San and Shengjindan. If blisters form after moxibustion, it is auspicious; if no blisters form, it is ominous. If sweating is achieved with a sweating remedy, it can be treated; without sweating, it is difficult to treat. If it becomes rotten with confusion, nausea, vomiting, and continuous bleeding, it leads to death.

    Zhu Abscess[46p]

    　　或问：颈上两耳后生疽何如？曰：此名杼疽，初不甚肿，但痛痒不时而出清水，渐渐长大，如玳瑁斑点者是也，亦名化骨疮。急服八阵散、夺命丹、活命饮加桔梗、柴胡。若过时溃烂，日久出骨者，大恶之证也。此证多生于积郁之人，七恶多见，犯禁者不治。
    　　　　外科正宗 【明　陈实功】

    　　　　　脑疽论

    　　夫脑疽者，俗称对口是也。但所发不同，其源有二。得于湿热交蒸，从外感受者轻；五脏蕴结，从内发外者重。其理何也？湿热之为病，天行气候，寒暑不调，节序温凉，阴阳失度，凡有体虚者，易于侵袭。项后虽属督脉，又主太阳寒水司行之道，所有侵袭，气血必凝，凝则后必为肿，此从外感受者。其患初起有头，多生正穴，三四日间多作焮痛，始生寒热，口和而干，色红根活，疮势渐高，形不散大，时止时疼，易脓易腐，饮食知味，起坐寻常，外势虽可畏，而内无七恶之证相干，此属阳证，其由从外来矣，故多不治可愈。[47p]

    Someone asked: What about the abscess that forms behind the ears on the neck? The answer: This is called "Zhu Abscess." Initially, it does not swell much, but there is persistent pain and itching, and clear fluid comes out irregularly. Gradually it grows larger, resembling the spots on a tortoise shell; it is also known as "Transforming Bone Ulcer." One should urgently take "Eight Formation Powder," "Life-Saving Elixir," and "Vitality Drink" with added Platycodon and Bupleurum. If it becomes ulcerated past the appropriate time and exposes bone over time, it is a serious sign. This condition often arises in people with accumulated depression, and it is most common in those with seven evils present; those who have broken prohibitions will not recover.

    Surgical Authenticity [Ming Dynasty, Chen Shigong]

    On Brain Abscess

    Brain abscesses are commonly referred to as "Dui Kou." However, their manifestations differ, having two sources. If acquired from a combination of dampness and heat, through external invasion, it is lighter; if arising from internal organ stagnation that manifests externally, it is more severe. Why is this? The illness of dampness and heat arises from the climate, where cold and heat are not balanced, seasonal temperature changes are irregular, and yin and yang are out of harmony. Those with a weak constitution are easily invaded. Although the area behind the neck belongs to the Governor Vessel, it also governs the pathway of solar cold and water; all invasions cause qi and blood to stagnate, and stagnation leads to swelling. This is the case when acquired externally. When the illness first arises, there is pain at the onset, often appearing at critical points, with rapid heat and pain in the first few days, sometimes accompanied by chills and fever. The mouth feels dry yet is not parched, the color is red with active roots, the ulcer raises gradually in severity, the shape is not diffuse or large, the pain comes and goes, and it is prone to pus and corruption. The ability to taste food remains, and there are no significant changes in appetite or activity. Although the external symptoms may seem fearsome, if there are no signs of the seven evils, this belongs to yang conditions, and since it arises from external sources, it often can resolve without treatment.[47p]

    所有五脏蕴结而成者重，其源有五：盖心主血，故心绪烦扰，煽动不宁，以致火旺而沸腾，行于项间，与寒水交滞而为肿者，一也。肝统筋，故恼怒伤肝，项乃三阳统筋之所，肝伤则血脉不潮，筋无荣养，凝结为肿，故项紧急强，痛不能转，则其患未溃前，肉色紫暗，坚硬漫肿，破流血水，不痛无脓，此等之证，皆肝气受伤者，二也。脾主肌肉，故思虑伤脾，脾气日损，又或膏粱损胃，胃汁干枯，以致中脘痞塞，气不运行，逆于肉里，乃生臃肿，其患外皮虽腐，而内坚不溃，口燥舌干，饮食不进，根脚走散，脓秽色败，此等之证，皆脾气受伤者，三也。[48p]

    All the internal organs that accumulate and become heavy have five sources: First, the heart governs blood, so when the heart is disturbed, it leads to restlessness and excessive heat, causing swelling as it interacts with cold water in the neck. Second, the liver regulates the tendons, and when anger injures the liver, it affects the blood vessels, resulting in a lack of nourishment for the tendons, which can lead to swelling. If the problem is not resolved, the skin may show a dark purple color, and it may feel hard and swollen. If it ruptures, blood and foul water may flow without pain or pus, indicating liver qi injury. Third, the spleen governs the muscles, so worries harm the spleen. As spleen qi declines or if rich foods affect the stomach, this can result in stagnation in the middle jiao, preventing qi from circulating and leading to swelling, where the outer skin may appear rotten but the inside remains hard and unruptured, accompanied by dry mouth and tongue, inability to eat, and foul discharge. These signs indicate spleen qi injury.[48p]

    肺主皮毛，故忧郁伤肺，肺伤则毛窍闭塞，腠理不通，气不舒畅，纵横经络，结而为肿，其形疮多平陷，色淡不华，皮腐脂流形如汤泼，气粗短促，面霉鼻掀，碌碌生痰，殷殷发嗽，此等之证，皆肺气受伤者，四也。肾主骨髓，故姿欲伤肾，肾伤则真阴之气败矣，真阴一败，相火自生，此火最能自升自降，或动或静，煎熬脏腑，消烁津液，更变形容，改换声音，疮形紫黑，脉数乖度，烦躁口干，随饮随渴，此等之证，皆肾气受伤者，五也。凡治此证，必内分虚实，外辨阴阳，体顺天时，察其病理。七日以前，疮势未成者，当通窍以汗发之；七日已后，病势已成，治当兼补以托之。此则毒不内攻，外无变证。[49p]

    The lungs govern the skin and hair, thus melancholy harms the lungs. When the lungs are injured, the pores close, the channels become obstructed, and the qi cannot flow smoothly. Stagnation throughout the meridians leads to swelling, with ulcers often appearing flat and depressed, having a pale and unremarkable color. The skin may become rotten and greasy like spilled soup, breathing becomes coarse and short, the face appears dull and the nose congested, leading to excessive phlegm and persistent coughing. These symptoms all indicate injury to lung qi.

    The kidneys govern the bones and marrow, thus excessive desires harm the kidneys. When the kidneys are injured, the true yin energy becomes depleted. Once the true yin fails, the fire of true yang arises on its own, which can fluctuate up and down, in motion or stillness, causing distress to the internal organs, consuming the body fluids, altering appearance and voice. The ulcers have a purple-black coloration, with a rapid and irregular pulse, restlessness and dry mouth, leading to thirst with drinking. These symptoms all indicate injury to kidney qi.

    In treating these conditions, one must first distinguish between deficiency and excess internally, and between yin and yang externally. One must align with seasonal changes, observing the pathology. If a sore has not yet formed after seven days, the channels should be opened to induce sweating. If seven days have passed and the condition has established itself, treatment must include both supplementation and drainage. This approach prevents internal toxicity and external transformation of symptoms.[49p]

    如药攻利太过，元气受伤，毒多难出。又敷围凉药，气血冰凝，则肌肉多死，反难腐溃。予尝治此及诸发背初起未成者，用铍针当顶点入知痛处，出其恶血，通其疮窍，随插蟾酥条直至疮底，外用膏盖；内服万灵丹、或蟾酥丸，发其大汗，解散内蕴之毒；次日患止，或肿或不肿，或痛或不痛，仍插仍贴，直至患顶肿高，根脚突起，四围裂缝有脓，方住插药。轻浅者，九日后吐出病根坚硬不化之物。毒甚者，不能顿然脱落，亦可渐腐成脓，为转重就轻之良法。外用玉红膏长肉，内服补托收敛，其患不久自愈。如阳证轻浅者，候自腐溃，不用前法针刺。如不肿不疼、灸亦不痛，阴证，尤当速用，不必迟延，此为移深居浅之大法也。　　看法[50p]

    If the medicinal attack on the excess of pathogens is too intense, the vital energy will be harmed, and the toxins will be difficult to eliminate. If one applies cooling medicines, the qi and blood freeze and凝凝, causing the flesh to die and becoming difficult to ulcerate. I have treated this condition, as well as early-stage back eruptions, by inserting a bamboo needle at the apex directly into the painful spot to expel the foul blood, opening the wound channels, and then inserting toad venom sticks until reaching the bottom of the sore, covering with medicated ointment externally. Internally, I prescribe the Universal Elixir or toad venom pills to induce profuse sweating and dissipate the internal toxins. The next day, the swelling might subside, with or without pain; continue the insertion and application until the swelling rises and a root-like protrusion appears with surrounding cracks filled with pus, at which point stop the needle insertion. For mild cases, after nine days, the hardened disease root will be expelled. In cases of severe toxicity where it cannot fall off immediately, it may gradually rot into pus, a good method for converting the severe into the mild. Use the Jade Red Ointment externally to help with flesh growth and internally take supplements to consolidate and contain; the issue will likely heal on its own soon. For light and shallow Yang conditions, wait for natural ulceration without the use of needle techniques. If it is painless and not swollen, even if moxibustion is applied without discomfort, this indicates a Yin condition, which should be addressed swiftly without delay; this is an important method for resolving deep-rooted issues that manifest superficially.[50p]

    　　初起，顶高根活，色红皮薄，作疼焮热，肿不开散者，顺。已成，无论偏正，疮形献起，疼痛发热，易脓易腐者，顺。已溃，脓稠，肉色红活，瘀腐易脱，焮肿渐消，痛减者，顺。溃后，腐脱，新肉便生，疮口渐敛，凝结痂脓，作痒者，顺。初生，一点黄泡，或似疙瘩，不肿不疼，自不知觉者，逆。已成，不发高肿，亦不焮痛，疮顶软陷，根脚平散者，逆。已溃，脓清，肉色紫黑，外皮不腐，内生臭秽，不食者，逆。腐肉虽尽，新肉不生，疮口散大，软陷无神，色败者，逆。　　治法[51p]

    Initially, if the top is high, the root is alive, the color is red, the skin is thin, and there is pain, heat, and swelling that does not disperse, it is favorable. Once it has formed, regardless of whether it is improper or proper, if the sore appears elevated, is painful, hot, and prone to pus and decay, it is favorable. After it has ulcerated, if the pus is thick, the flesh is red and alive, bruises are easy to detach, swelling gradually decreases, and pain diminishes, it is favorable. Following ulceration, if decay has separated, new flesh begins to grow, the sore gradually closes, scabs form, and there is itching, it is favorable.

    If initially a small yellow blister appears, resembling a bump, it does not swell or hurt, and the person is unaware, it is unfavorable. Once it has formed, if it does not swell high or hurt, with the top of the sore soft and sunken, and the base flat and dispersed, it is unfavorable. After it has ulcerated, if the pus is clear, the flesh is purple-black, the outer skin is not decayed, but there is a foul smell emanating from within, and it does not heal, it is unfavorable. Even if the rotten flesh is completely gone, if new flesh does not grow, the sore widens, softens, lacks vitality, and its color fades, it is unfavorable.

    Treatment methods.[51p]

    　　初起，有头或无头，大痛或不痛，俱隔蒜灸，兼服解毒。已成，坚硬发热，焮痛，口干便秘者，邪在内也，宜泄之。坚肿不痛，发热恶寒，头疼四肢拘急者，兼发表攻里。肿硬日深，形色紫黑，外皮不腐，内脓不溃，宜行拔法。肿强，头面焮热，口燥，恶心呕吐者，邪在上也，宜清之。焮热肿痛，红色光亮，疼苦有时，内脓胀痛者，急开之。将溃不溃，微热微红，不作腐溃者，脾胃虚也，宜补之。溃后腐肉不脱，脓水清稀，肿痛仍作者，当大养气血。大便多溏，小便短濇，自汗食少，脉细身凉，温中健脾。[52p]

    At the onset, whether there is a head or not, whether there is great pain or not, it should be treated with garlic moxibustion, along with detoxification herbs. If it has formed, is hard and hot, and causes pain, with dry mouth and constipation, it indicates internal evil and should be purged. If it is hard and swollen, without pain, accompanied by fever and chills, and headaches with stiff limbs, both expelling and purging methods should be used. If the swelling becomes deeper and the color appears purple-black, with intact outer skin and no internal pus discharge, the method of extraction should be employed. If the swelling is strong, with a hot face, dry mouth, nausea, and vomiting, it indicates that the evil is above and should be cleared. If it is hot, swollen, and painful, with a bright red color, periodically painful, and internal pus causing swelling and pain, it should be urgently opened up. If it is about to ulcerate but remains slightly warm and slightly red without forming a decay, it indicates spleen and stomach deficiency and should be nourished. After ulceration, if the necrotic flesh does not fall off, with clear and thin pus, and the swelling and pain continues, one should greatly nourish qi and blood. If there is frequent diarrhea, concentrated and scanty urine, spontaneous sweating, little appetite, with a thin pulse and cool body, warmth should be applied to strengthen the spleen.[52p]

    　　　　　瘰疬论

    　　夫瘰疬者，有风毒、热毒、气毒之异，又有瘰疬、筋疬、痰疬之殊。风毒者，外受风寒，缚于经络，其患先寒后热，结核浮肿。热毒者，天时亢热，暑中三阳，或内食膏粱厚味，酿结成患，色红微热，结核坚肿。气毒者，四时杀厉之气感冒而成，其患耳项胸腋骤成肿块，令人寒热头眩，项强作痛。瘰疬者，累累如贯珠，连接三五枚，此不作作　原作「足」，据《外科正宗》瘰疬论改。[53p]

    Discussion on Scrofula

    Scrofula, which has variations of wind poisons, heat poisons, and qi poisons, also has distinctions among scrofula, muscle scrofula, and phlegm scrofula. Wind poison arises from exposure to wind and cold, binding in the meridians, where the condition first presents with cold followed by heat, resulting in swollen nodules. Heat poison occurs in excessively hot weather, during the height of summer, or from consuming rich foods, leading to red and slightly warm colors with firm, swollen nodules. Qi poison develops from the harshness of seasonal changes, resulting in sudden swelling in areas such as the ears, neck, chest, and armpits, causing chills, fever, dizziness, and pain in the neck. Scrofula appears clustered like strings of pearls, with connections of three to five lumps.[53p]

    寒热，其患得于悞食虫蚁鼠残不洁之物，又或汗液宿茶陈水混入而餐，其患先小后大，初不觉疼，久方知痛。筋疬者，忧愁思虑，暴怒伤肝，盖肝主筋，故令筋缩，结蓄成核，生于项侧筋间，形如棋子坚硬，大小不一，或陷或突，久则虚赢，多生寒热，劳怒则甚。痰疬者，饮食冷热不调，饥饱喜怒不常，多致脾气不能传运，遂成痰结，初起如梅如李，生及遍身，久则微红，后必溃破，易于收敛。凡观此证，别其风毒者，散其风，除其毒，如防风解毒汤之类是也。热毒者，清其脾，泻其热，连翘消毒饮之类是也。[54p]

    Cold and heat derive from consuming unclean remnants left by insects, ants, and mice, or from sweat mixed with old tea and stale water. The affliction starts small and gradually becomes serious; initially, there is no pain, but over time it becomes noticeable.

    Muscle knots, or "Jin Li," arise from sorrowful thoughts and explosive anger, which harm the liver. Since the liver governs the muscles, it causes them to contract, forming hard knots that appear between the neck and muscles, resembling the hardness of chess pieces, varying in size, some recessed and others protruding. Over time, they can become hollow and produce both cold and heat; excessive labor and anger worsen the condition.

    Phlegm knots arise from improper regulation of food and drink, instability in hunger and satiety, and fluctuating emotions, leading to an inability of the spleen to transport and transform, resulting in phlegm accumulation. Initially, it resembles small plums or cherries on the body, turning slightly red over time, and eventually rupturing, which makes it easier to contain.

    In observing these symptoms, one should identify the wind and toxin; to disperse the wind and eliminate the toxin, remedies like "Fang Feng Jie Du Tang" are effective. For heat toxin, it is necessary to cleanse the spleen and drain the heat, using formulas such as "Lian Qiao Xiao Du Yin."[54p]

    气毒者，调其血，和其气，藿香正气散之类是也。瘰疬者，散其坚，和其血，散肿溃坚汤之类是也。筋疬者，清其肝，解其郁，柴胡清肝汤之类是也。痰疬者，豁其痰，行其气，芩连二陈汤之类是也。又有寡妇尼僧，鳏夫庶妾，志不得发，思不得遂，积想在心，过伤精力，此劳中所得者，往往有之，最为难治。有此，先养心血，次开郁结，益肾安神，疏肝快膈，如归脾汤、益气养荣汤，俱加香附、青皮、山栀、贝母、木香之类是也。[55p]

    For those with toxic Qi, regulate their blood and harmonize their Qi, using formulas like Huoxiang Zhengqi San. For scrofula, disperse the hardness and harmonize the blood, employing formulas like San Juan Guo Jian Tang. For muscle and tendon issues, clear the liver and relieve stagnation with formulas like Chai Hu Qing Gan Tang. For phlegm-related issues, expel phlegm and move Qi, using formulas like Qin Lian Er Chen Tang. Additionally, there are widowed nuns, widowers, and secondary wives, whose aspirations remain unfulfilled, and thoughts accumulate in their hearts, which can overly exhaust their essence and energy, often creating difficult-to-treat conditions. In such cases, first nourish the heart and blood, then relieve stagnation, benefit the kidneys, calm the spirit, and soothe the liver and diaphragm, utilizing formulas like Gui Pi Tang and Yi Qi Yang Rong Tang, adding ingredients like Xiang Fu, Qing Pi, Shan Zhi Shi, Bei Mu, and Mu Xiang.[55p]

    又男人不宜太阳青筋，潮热咳嗽，自汗盗汗；女人又忌眼内红丝，经闭骨蒸，五心烦热。男妇有此，后必变为痨瘵难治之证。但此体实者，初起可服散肿溃坚攻利之药，得效者十中三四。有不察虚实，尽剂追伐，损伤元气，致成坏病者，十有八九。此非患者之命，自出医人之手。予常治初起成核，服前药未效者，用针刺核内，深入三四分，用冰蛳散捻成条子，插入核内，糊纸封上，待至二七后，核子自然落出，随用红黑二膏搽贴，内服补剂，不久便愈。又常见螌蝥、牵牛、巴霜、大黄追蚀等用，往往致其危亡者多矣，切宜戒之。　　看法[56p]

    Men should avoid symptoms like blue veins on the forehead, hot flashes with cough, and excessive sweating. Women should avoid having red threads in the eyes, irregular menstruation, and a feeling of heat in the bones, along with restlessness in their hearts. If either men or women experience these symptoms, they may later develop difficult-to-treat tuberculosis. However, those with sufficient vitality in the early stages may take herbs to disperse swelling and soften nodules; about 30-40% may find relief. If one is not aware of their condition and uses strong doses recklessly, it may damage vital energy, leading to severe illnesses—this is often not the patient's fate but rather results from the actions of the physician. I often treat early-stage nodules; if previous medications are ineffective, I use needles to pierce the nodule deeply, inserting a thin strip of ice powder and sealing it with paper. After approximately 14 days, the nodule will naturally fall out, and applying red and black plasters along with internal tonics usually leads to recovery in no time. I have also frequently observed that using substances like rashes, morning glories, and certain purgative herbs has often led to severe outcomes; thus, one should exercise caution with them.[56p]

    　　初起，核高肿痛，色红软活，微作寒热，肩项不强者，易。已成，根不坚硬，内无小核相丛，脾健气血不衰者，易。已溃，脓稠，肉色红活，核肿渐消，肩项自便渐敛者，顺。溃后，易消易敛，气体平和，胸膈宽利，饮食知味者，顺。未成，形体消瘦，寒热往来，结核顽硬，痰嗽相兼者，险。已成，核坚连续如珠，大小不等，项强筋急，脉虚者，险。已溃，脓水清稀，肌肉消烁，自汗盗汗，寒热不睡者，逆。溃后，阴虚烦躁，作渴泄秘，男子骨蒸，女子经闭，俱逆。　　治法[57p]

    At the outset, if the tumor is swollen and painful, red and soft, with slight chills and fever, and the shoulder and neck are not stiff, it is easy to treat. Once formed, if the root is not hard, there are no small clusters inside, and the spleen is healthy with no loss of energy or blood, it is also easy to treat. If it has ulcerated, with thick pus, red and moist flesh, the tumor gradually shrinking, and the shoulder and neck easing over time, it is favorable. After ulceration, if it is easy to resolve and contract, with a calm energy, broad chest and smooth digestion, and a good appetite, it is favorable. If not formed, with a thin physique, alternating chills and fever, stubborn hard lumps, and accompanying cough with phlegm, it is dangerous. If formed, with hard lumps that feel connected like beads, of varying sizes, stiff neck and tense muscles, and weak pulse, it is dangerous. If it has ulcerated, with clear and thin pus, muscle wasting, spontaneous sweating, night sweats, and persistent chills and fever, it is adverse. After ulceration, if there are symptoms of yin deficiency with irritability, thirst, constipation, bone steaming in men, and menstrual irregularities in women, it is also adverse.

    Treatment methods.[57p]

    　　初起肿痛，憎寒壮热，四肢拘急，项强头眩者，表散之。肿硬发热，便秘口干，胸膈不利，恶心脉实，宜利之。膏粱厚味，醇酒积热，湿痰凝结而成，化痰降火清中。忧思过度，郁怒伤肝，筋缩结核者，宜养血开郁疏肝。房欲劳伤，阴虚晡热，自汗咳嗽，形消瘦者，滋肾健脾。失利忘名，怀抱郁结，积想在心，所如不得，乖隔阴阳，虚嗷岁月，所得此者，精血俱伤，先养正气，次治标病。坚而不溃，腐而溃之；溃而不敛，补而敛之。皆活法也。
    　　　　石室秘箓 【清　陈士铎】

    　　　　　瘰串

    　　瘰串，乃鼠食之物，人不知食之，多生此病。然亦有郁气者，乃易成而不愈也。方用白芍、白芥子、紫背天葵、茯苓、香附、当归各三两，人参、柴胡各五钱，蒲公英一两，白朮五两，砂仁二钱，各为末，米饭为丸，如细米一半大，每日白滚水送下三钱，日三服，一月即消，二月全愈。古今图书集成医部全录卷一百六十七[58p]

    When the initial symptoms are swelling and pain, with aversion to cold and strong heat, limbs feeling tense, stiff neck, and dizziness, it is advisable to disperse these symptoms. For hard swelling with heat, constipation, dry mouth, uncomfortable feeling in the chest, nausea, and a strong pulse, one should promote bowel movements. Accumulated heat from rich foods and strong wines, as well as damp phlegm leading to stagnation, should be transformed to clear heat and resolve phlegm. Overthinking and excessive worry harm the liver, causing retraction and knots, so nourishing blood and releasing stagnant emotions is advised. If there is exhaustion from sexual activity, Yin deficiency with evening heat, spontaneous sweating, coughing, and emaciation, one should nourish the kidneys and strengthen the spleen. Those who feel lost and forgetful, with pent-up emotions and obsessive thoughts, find themselves separated from yin and yang, suffering from the passage of time, will injure both essence and blood. First, nourish the righteous Qi, then treat the superficial condition. Firm yet not collapsing, decayed yet not rotting; rotting yet not healing, supplement and heal it. These are all methods of revitalization.

    As for "Luo Chuan," it is a condition resulting from consuming mouse-eaten food, which many do not realize leads to this illness. However, those with stagnant Qi may easily develop it and find it difficult to cure. The prescription includes three taels each of white peony, white mustard seed, purple-backed celestial vine, poria, cyperus, and angelica, five qian each of ginseng and bupleurum, one tael of dandelion, five taels of white atractylodes, and two qian of amomum, ground into powder. Make into pills the size of a small grain of rice, taking three qian with white boiling water three times daily; in a month it will dissipate, and in two months it will be completely cured.[58p]

    Jiawei Shengshi Decoction is used for treating wind-damp conditions in the initial stage. Ingredients include Qianghuo, Duhuo, Gaoben, Fangfeng, Manjingzi, Chuanxiong, Cangzhu (soaked in water, then fried), Huangbo (fried with wine), Jingjie, and Licorice (pre-fried). For deep-seated lower back pain, add Shufu and Fangji. If extremely deficient, remove Huangbo and add Ren Shen.

    Yangshen Decoction, from Dongyuan, is used for treating Qi deficiency with excess heat in the initial stage. Grind them and take five qian per dose, boiling in two cups of water, then strain and consume slightly warm, any time.

    Jiao Fu San, from Benshifang (the same source), is used for treating stiffness and pain in the neck and along the back and hips, which cannot be moved. The formula consists of one piece of Da Fuzi, prepared, peeled, and the seed removed, then ground into a powder.[60p]

    Right now, for every two large coins, take twenty grains of Sichuan pepper, fill with white flour, add a cup and a half of water, and seven slices of ginger. Boil until reduced by seven minutes, remove the pepper and add salt, then take it on an empty stomach. I had a relative suffering from this condition; after trying various medicines without effect, I recalled a method from "Qianjin Sui" for kidney energy attacking the back. I administered this formula, and he was cured after one dose.

    Papaya Decoction - for the previous condition.
    Take two papayas, remove the core. Grind two liang of myrrh and two and a half qian of frankincense. Place these two ingredients inside the papaya, cover it, secure with bamboo skewers, and steam over rice for three or four times until it becomes a paste. Take three to five spoonfuls, mixed with Shengdi juice. Half a cup of Shengdi juice, combined with two cups of non-ash wine, take eight portions, warmed to be consumed.

    Return to the Head Powder - for tightness and urgency in the neck and shoulders, or for difficulty in turning the head after a strain.
    Take two qian each of Wormwood and tangerine peel, and one qian each of Ephedra (with the stems removed), Chuan Xiong, Bai Zhi, Platycodon, and immature bitter orange (warmed), along with stir-fried silkworms (with the silk removed), stir-fried ginger, honey-fried licorice, Qiang Huo, Du Huo, and papaya. Add ginger and scallions, and decoct with water for consumption.

    Qianghuo Shengshi Decoction (from Dongyuan) - for cold and dampness in the Taiyang channel, with tightness in the neck or an inability to look back.
    Take two qian each of Qiang Huo and Du Huo, five fen each of Chuan Xiong and Vitex, one qian each of dry roots, Fang Feng, and licorice. Grind these together, make a paste, and decoct with water for consumption.[61p]

    Ge Gen Decoction
    For treating a stiff neck with no sweating and aversion to wind, indicating a full condition.

    Da Xian Xiong Decoction: For treating misapplied purging, and tightness in the chest due to Taiyin.

    • Rhubarb 6 ounces, Glauber's salt 1 ounce, Liujiao 0.1 ounce.

    Si Ni Decoction: For treating severe cold excess.

    • Prepared licorice 2 ounces, one piece of Aconite (unpeeled, broken into 8 pieces), dried ginger 1.5 ounces.
      Take these three ingredients, grind, and add 3 liters of water. Boil to yield 1.2 liters, strain, and take warm in two doses. Stronger individuals may use a larger piece of Aconite and 3 ounces of dried ginger, taking it cool.

    Xiao Chai Hu Decoction: For treating neck stiffness, fullness under the ribs, body heat with aversion to wind, and thirst with sweating in hands and feet.

    • Chai Hu 0.5 pound, Huang Qin, Ren Shen, prepared licorice, and fresh ginger (sliced), each 3 ounces; Ban Xia 0.5 sheng (a measuring unit), rinsed; 12 jujubes, split.
      Combine these seven ingredients with 12 liters of water, boil to yield 6 liters, strain, and boil again to yield 3 liters. Take 1 liter warm, three times a day.[63p]
